04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Harren the Red had proved himself to be a powerful enemy during the Second Dornish War, wanting to take account of all he had lost in his previous rebellion against King Aegon I Targaryen. His defeat came swiftly when he was brought to bay in a village west of the Gods Eye, where Lord Alyn Stokeworth, Hand of the King, and Bernarr Brune, Commander of the Kingsguard fought for Alexander Targaryen's honor. Harren and his men perished naked on that riverside battle whilst Davos Baratheon, Samwell Tarly and No-Nose Dondarrion conferred their highest honors upon Lord Alyn Stokeworth with bestowal from Queen Aerea Tyrell herself. Even Ellyn Caron meekly accepted her greatest failure and bowed before Allard Royce and Goren Greyjoy - both infamous commanders loyal to Prince Maegor Targaryen himself.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: But the amity between the Dragon’s sons did not long endure.
events: amity between the Dragon’s sons did not long endure
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The amity between the Dragon’s sons did not long endure. Out in King's Landing and across Westeros, members of House Tyrell, Baratheon and Targaryen alike conferred their blessings upon their children in an effort to quell any tension that could brew up between them. The People of Kings Landing watched on meekly as the Deria Martell bestowed a generous dowry onto her son, while Allard Royce gifted his daughter Alysanne with jewels from all across the land. Goren Greyjoy bested even these grand displays by having his men build a tower tall enough to reach the gods themselves. However despite this great show of wealth, it seemed nothing would convince Prince Maegor who had already sworn fealty to no-one since he'd been imprisoned at Visenya's Hill by his aunt Dowager Queen Visenya Targaryen.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: It may be that conflict was inevitable, for the two brothers had very different natures. King Aenys loved his wife, his children, and his people, and wished only to be loved in turn. Sword and lance had lost whatever appeal they ever had for him. Instead His Grace dabbled in alchemy, astronomy, and astrology, delighted in music and dance, wore the finest silks, samites, and velvets, and enjoyed the company of maesters, septons, and wits. His brother, Maegor, taller, broader, and fearsomely strong, had no patience for any of that, but lived for war, tourneys, and battle. He was rightly regarded as one of the finest knights in Westeros, though his savagery in the field and his harshness toward defeated foes was oft remarked upon as well. King Aenys sought always to please; when faced with difficulties, he would answer with soft words, whereas Maegor’s reply was ever steel and fire. Grand Maester Gawen wrote that Aenys trusted everyone, Maegor no one. The king was easily influenced, Gawen observed, swaying this way and that like a reed in the wind, like as not to heed whichever counselor last had his ear. Prince Maegor, on the other hand, was rigid as an iron rod, unyielding, unbending.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: As King Aenys loved to dally and delighted in the finer things of life, he wore the finest clothes, lived freely among his people like Aegon's I the Conqueror had done before him - yet he had no patience for those who did not bend to his will. Grand Maester Gawen sought counsel from His Grace but in answer was shouted down, as King Aenys remarked upon the swaying of others to his Heed and even different customs with a fearsomely strong hand. All maesters regarded him with fear and awe as his savagery in the field was unyielding and unbending.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Despite such differences, the sons of the Dragon continued to rule together amicably for the best part of two years. But in 39 AC, Queen Alyssa gave King Aenys yet another heir, a girl she named Vaella, who sadly died in the cradle not long after. Perhaps it was this continued proof of the queen’s fertility that drove Prince Maegor to do what he did. Whatever the reason, the prince shocked the realm and the king both when he suddenly announced that Lady Ceryse was barren, and he had therefore taken a second wife in Alys Harroway, daughter of the new Lord of Harrenhal.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Queen Alyssa continued to rule with King Aenys amicably, despite the shock that was felt when he suddenly announced he had taken a second wife. The Queen had a daughter Vaella with him, which was proof of the queen’s fertility and she also made sure Lady Ceryse and Alys Harroway from House Harroway were treated amicably at court. Lord of Harrenhal and others in the Realm all accepted this change uncomfortably but King Aenys did not heed their fears as he was fearsomely strong yet had a fine way about his savagery in the field. He (un)yielding (un)bending nature meant Queen Alyssa's position at court would remain unchanged for many years to come.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The wedding was performed on Dragonstone, under the aegis of the Dowager Queen Visenya. As the castle septon refused to officiate, Maegor and his new bride were joined in a Valyrian rite, “wed by blood and fire.” The marriage took place without the leave, knowledge, or presence of King Aenys. When it became known, the two half-brothers quarreled bitterly. Nor was His Grace alone in his wroth. Manfred Hightower, father of Lady Ceryse, made protest to the king, demanding that Lady Alys be put aside. And in the Starry Sept at Oldtown, the High Septon went even further, denouncing Maegor’s marriage as sin and fornication, and calling the prince’s new bride “this whore of Harroway.” No true son or daughter of the Seven would ever bow to such, he thundered.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Prince Maegor, who had traveled to Dragonstone for his wedding officiated by the septon, quarreled with King Aenys when the High Septon made protest against the Valyrian marriage customs demanding the acceptance of multiple wives. Unperturbed, King Aenys refused and denounced such customs in a deep thundered voice that permeated across Dragonstone Castle. Lady Ceryse accompanied by her daughter Alys were both shocked while many pious lords present gasped at what they had heard. This further legitimized Queen Visenya Targaryen’s sudden announcement of taking a second wife to prove her fertility and continued rule alongside Queen Alyssa amicably back in The Realm with King Aenys.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Prince Maegor remained defiant. His father had taken both of his sisters to wife, he pointed out; the strictures of the Faith might rule lesser men, but not the blood of the dragon. No words of King Aenys could heal the wound his brother’s words thus opened, and many pious lords throughout the Seven Kingdoms condemned the marriage, and began to speak openly of “Maegor’s Whore.”
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Prince Maegor had remained steadfast in his commitment to take a wife and rule alongside King Aenys. When they journeyed to Oldtown - a place of healing and piety - stoked with Valyrian marriage customs, the High Septon opened the union between Prince Maegor and Lady Ceryse of House Hightower, sister of Lord Manfred. Yet when several pious lords spoke out against this defiance, denouncing such a sacrilegious act, the Dowager Queen Visenya thundered them into submission; for her brother King Maegor I Targaryen had declared that any man who protested at his niece’s marriage would be condemned. As she opened up court to speak on behalf of her son, it said all there was to know: no amount of protesting or condemning could tear apart what fate had put together.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Vexed and angry, King Aenys gave his brother a choice: put Alys Harroway aside and return to Lady Ceryse, or suffer five years of exile. Prince Maegor chose exile. In 40 AC he departed for Pentos, taking Lady Alys, Balerion his dragon, and the sword Blackfyre with him. (It is said that Aenys requested that his brother return Blackfyre, to which Prince Maegor replied, “Your Grace is welcome to try and take her from me.”) Lady Ceryse was left abandoned in King’s Landing.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Prince Maegor was vexed. He had been left abandoned by his father King Aenys, who had put aside their marriage in light of the ensuing chaos. So he did what any angry Targaryan prince would do: he departed Pentos with Lady Ceryse and Balerion, as well as the famous Blackfyre. Lord of Alys Harroway, a noblewoman from Oldtown, joined them on his quest to prove that despite being condemned and spoken against by many pious lords and septons, his time for ruling could truly heal Westeros from the turmoil that has opened up since Aegon's reign ended. An entourage filled with squires and handsome young men followed closely behind him as they set off to King's Landing once more - not just to reclaim his throne but also to see if he could right all the wrongs which had been visited upon him. He left behind Poxy Jeyne Poore in exile despite her son hanging onto her hand tightly unwilling for her mother to go away; yet Maegor remained defiant in restoring justice to will be served…

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: To replace his brother as Hand, King Aenys turned to Septon Murmison, a pious cleric said to be able to heal the sick by the laying on of hands. (The king had him lay hands on Lady Ceryse’s belly every night, in the hopes that his brother might repent his folly if his lawful wife could be made fertile, but the lady soon grew weary of the nightly ritual and departed King’s Landing for Oldtown, where she rejoined her father in the Hightower.) No doubt His Grace the king hoped the choice would appease the Faith. If so, he was wrong. Septon Murmison could no more heal the realm than he could make Ceryse Hightower fecund. The High Septon continued to thunder, and all through the realm the lords in their halls spoke of the king’s weakness. “How can he rule the Seven Kingdoms when he cannot even rule his brother?” they said.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: King Aenys and Septon Murmison led the nightly ritual in King's Landing. The solemn procession was held to help heal, replace, and make fecund His Grace the king's subjects while they thundered the Seven laws and prayed for pious rulers. As they reached Oldtown Hightower, the High Septon identified all in attendance with a laying on of hands. Little did anyone expect that this simple ceremony could have been an omen of things to come when King Aenys' angry and vexed orders put aside much of his court, who departed soon after he left them abandoned in exile as he said his last goodbyes.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The king remained oblivious to the discontent in the realm. Peace had returned, his troublesome brother was across the narrow sea, and a great new castle had begun to rise atop Aegon’s High Hill: built all in pale red stone, the king’s new seat would be larger and more lavish than Dragonstone, with massive walls and barbicans and towers capable of withstanding any enemy. The Red Keep, the people of King’s Landing named it. Its building had become the king’s obsession. “My descendants shall rule from here for a thousand years,” His Grace declared. Perhaps thinking of those descendants, in 41 AC Aenys Targaryen made a disastrous blunder and announced his intention to give the hand of his daughter Rhaena in marriage to her brother Aegon, heir to the Iron Throne.
adjectives: massive walls and barbicans and towers
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: King Aenys had returned from the narrow sea with his younger brother Aegon after discontent in the realm had risen. His arrival, accompanied by such an imposing entourage at Aegon's High Hill, spoke volumes of their rise and soon after he set in to building the Red Keep - a stronghold befitting of a monarch capable of withstanding any threats that were to come. After he declared himself king, oblivious to any of troublesome matters in Westeros, and decided to name the castle walls built from pale red stone as The Red Keep for all succeeding kings and queens. Massive walls and barbicans and towers seemed only appropriate for peace - something which remained elusive since Jaehaerys Targaryen declare ‘lawful rulers make peaceful realms’ coupled with Septon Murmison's nightly ritual laying on hands to heal those stricken and make them fecund once again - was marked down as teaching amongst pious lords across seven kingdoms.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The princess was eighteen, the prince fifteen. They had been close since childhood, playmates when young. Though Aegon had never claimed a dragon of his own, he had ascended into the skies more than once with his sister, on Dreamfyre. Lean and handsome and growing taller every year, Aegon was said by many to be the very image of his grandsire at the same age. Three years of service as a squire had sharpened his prowess with sword and axe, and he was widely regarded as the best young lance in all the realm. Of late, many a young maiden had cast her eye upon the prince, and Aegon was not indifferent to their charms. “If the prince is not wed,” Grand Maester Gawen wrote the Citadel, “His Grace may soon have a bastard grandchild to contend with.”
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Princess Alysanne had just ascended to her seventeenth name day, soon to be eighteen in a matter of weeks. Her brother Aegon had sharpened with age and faced the troubles of the realm strong and composed, she watched close as he grew taller and handsomer each day. Grand Maester Gawen reminded them time was fleeting while they both still stood together beside Dreamfyre at fifteen its beauty best remembered late. It seemed that everything around them had grown more turbulent since their father's return from across the Narrow Sea, yet oblivious to it all were his two children, standing tall amidst the turmoil created by their father’s rise to power--the building of Red Keep with its pale red stone walls and barbicans ever-withstanding foes.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Princess Rhaena had many a suitor as well, but unlike her brother she gave encouragement to none of them. She preferred to spend her days with her siblings, her dogs and cats, and her newest favorite, Alayne Royce, daughter to the Lord of Runestone…a plump and homely girl, but so cherished that Rhaena sometimes took her flying on the back of Dreamfyre, just as she did her brother Aegon. More often, though, Rhaena took to the skies by herself. After her sixteenth nameday, the princess declared herself a woman grown, “free to fly where I will.”
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Princess Rhaena enjoyed the encouragement of her older brother Aegon, whom she cherished and preferred to spend time with over Grand Maester Gawen. On her sixteenth nameday, she took Lord Alayne Royce of Runestone as a suiter and he quickly became her newest favorite. They talked for hours; for he found her to be plump and homely contrary to the lean and handsome girls from which he was used to but even still declared that none could compare to his Princess Rhaena. Many more suiters came thereafter but none held a candle to him in her eyes.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: And fly she did. Dreamfyre was seen as far away as Harrenhal, Tarth, Runestone, Gulltown. It was whispered (though never proved) that on one of these flights Rhaena surrendered the flower of her maidenhead to a lowborn lover. A hedge knight, one story had it; others named him a singer, a blacksmith’s son, a village septon. In light of these tales, some have suggested that Aenys might have felt a need to see his daughter wed as soon as possible. Regardless of the truth of that surmise, at eighteen Rhaena was certainly of an age to marry, three years older than her mother and father had been when they were wed.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Princess Rhaena had taken a newfound interest in her dragon Dreamfyre and cherished the special moments they shared together. As she flew across Runestone, Harrenhal and Tarth, she could feel herself falling further under the spell of this new, beloved pet. She eventually surrendered to its power and whispered it's name - Dreamfyre - as people around them suggested lowborn choices like a hedge knight or a blacksmith's son for marriage proposals; Rhaena declared she would never wed but none of their suggestions felt right. It wasn't until she returned to Gulltown from her sixteenth nameday celebration with Lord of Runestone that an idea was presented that proved worthy of consideration; Alys Harroway, daughter of Lord Allard Royce, who reminded the princess so much of herself before Westeros' gaze took its toll on her homely features.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Given the traditions and practices of House Targaryen, a match between his two eldest children must have seemed the obvious course to King Aenys. The affection between Rhaena and Aegon was well- known, and neither raised any objection to the marriage; indeed, there is much to suggest that both had been anticipating just such a partnership since they had first played together in the nurseries of Dragonstone and the Aegonfort.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: King Aenys and Rhaena's marriage must have seemed to be an obvious and well-known event in Westeros. Everyone was anticipating the union of one of the major Targaryen Houses, especially with such renowned places like Dragonstone and Aegonfort acting as its venues. Little did they know about Dreamfyre's lowborn origin, who had surrendered her maidenhead to a hedge knight in Runestone or Gulltown as she whispered his name into the night air? In some strange fashion, this union symbolized not only the beginning but also gave hope for reunification of all Seven Kingdoms on both sides of Narrow Sea.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The storm that greeted the king’s announcement took them all by surprise, though the warning signs had been plain enough for those with the wit to read them. The Faith had condoned, or at the very least ignored, the marriage of the Conqueror and his sisters, but it was not willing to do the same for their grandchildren. From the Starry Sept came a blistering condemnation, denouncing the marriage of brother to sister as an obscenity. Any children born of such a union would be “abominations in the sight of gods and men,” the Father of the Faithful proclaimed, in a declaration that was read by ten thousand septons throughout the Seven Kingdoms.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The King and Conqueror, Aegon I Targaryen, was greeted with a roaring cheer by the people of Westeros as he entered the Starry Sept with his sisters and grandchildren to witness the infamous stormy marriage of brother to sister. The pious lords overlooked the condoned Valyrian marriage customs ignoring and denouncing anyone who read aloud their blistering obscenities about the Targaryens. Knowing his own well-known ancestry, His Grace must have seemed more aware than ever before that he was raising up an even greater dynasty than those before him which came from Old Valyria.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Aenys Targaryen was infamous for his indecision, yet here, faced with the fury of the Faith, he stiffened and grew stubborn. The Dowager Queen Visenya advised him that he had but two choices; he must abandon the marriage and find new matches for his son and daughter or mount his dragon, Quicksilver, to fly to Oldtown to burn the Starry Sept down around the High Septon’s head. King Aenys did neither. Instead he simply persisted.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The Dowager Queen Visenya Targaryen froze in shock as the Storm of Aegon I Targaryen swept through and she witnessed the marriage of her brother Aenys to his own sister Visenya. People from all corners of The Realm and beyond gathered at Starry Sept to witness this solemn but unheard event, many chosen attendees were either greeted or accepted by the King, some condoned it and others just ignore or even denounced such a practice in vioce or actions. Lady Ceryse Hightower from House Hightower, whose eyes had been reading an old book sent from Her High Holiness in Oldtown grew stiff feeling rage overwhelm her while watching the proceedings; she advised Lord Jon Lychester with who she was conveying that they ought-to mount their horses and fly away right away before it was too late. But Lord Lychester persisted in staying there until the blistering obscenity came to an end while Lady Ceryse's fury increased with its every breath.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: On the day of the wedding, the streets outside the Sept of Remembrance—built atop the Hill of Rhaenys, and named in honor of the Dragon’s fallen queen—were lined with Warrior’s Sons in gleaming silver armor, making note of each of the wedding guests as they passed by, afoot, ahorse, or in litters. The wiser lords, perhaps expecting that, had stayed away.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: As Aenys Targaryen and Dowager Queen Visenya passed by the Starry Sept in Oldtown, they stopped at the Sept of Remembrance to attend Rhaenys's wedding. Lines of Warrior's Sons lined up along the aisle as they solemnly passed by, every face carefully watching them as they made their way down. The Hill of Rhaenys gleamed with more than just sunlight that day; wisdom could be seen in many of the melancholic faces around them. Little did they know that on that day a movement which would eventually shape modern Westeros was born when Lord Father decided to stay away from her daughter's wedding, a decision which marked his refusal to conform to Valyrian marriage customs and indicated an era full of freedom for all Seven Kingdoms.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Those who did come to bear witness saw more than a wedding. At the feast afterward, King Aenys compounded his misjudgment by granting the title Prince of Dragonstone to his presumptive heir, Prince Aegon. A hush fell over the hall at those words, for all present knew that title had hitherto belonged to Prince Maegor. At the high table, Queen Visenya rose and stalked from the hall without the king’s leave. That night she mounted Vhagar and returned to Dragonstone, and it is written that when her dragon passed before the moon, that orb turned as red as blood.
events: granting the title Prince of Dragonstone
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: King Aenys, his brothers Prince Aegon and Prince Maegor, along with Queen Visenya arrived at Dragonstone to bear witness to a special event - the granting of the title 'Prince of Dragonstone' to Aegon. Afterward they joined in on a great feast that was compounded by this remarkable union.  Lord Tyrell of Rollingford and Princess Deria, daughter of the Old Lord Father, had been lined up on either side as people passed by them. From far away Westeros came Kingsguard led by Ser Harys Hill who had stayed away from the glimmering Sept of Remembrance before returning for this occasion. The Wise Dowager Queen Visenya Targaryen took particular pride in pronouncing her nephew as her country's prince, previously having held only a presumptive claim prior thereto.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Aenys Targaryen did not seem to comprehend the extent to which he had roused the realm against him. Eager to win back the favor of the smallfolk, he decreed that the prince and princess would make a royal progress through the realm, no doubt thinking of the cheers that had greeted him everywhere he went on his own progress. Wiser perhaps than her father, Princess Rhaena asked his leave to bring her dragon, Dreamfyre, with them, but Aenys forbade it. As Prince Aegon had not yet ridden a dragon, the king feared that the lords and commons might think his son unmanly if they saw his wife on dragonback and him upon a palfrey.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Aenys Targaryen had returned from the Golden Tooth to Loamsdown and made his way to King’s Landing where he was met with an entourage of Westerosi lords, knights and wise smallfolk. He asked around for Lord Corbray, a known friend of his father Aegon I Targaryen and master of Oldstone Hall. Everyone seemed eager to answer his call but nevertheless were unable to comprehend why Aenys wanted him as only whispers had been heard about the lord's sudden disappearance from the realm a few moons prior. This roused suspicion in everyone but regardless they all obliged their king by riding off northward together in search of Lord Corbray. However little did they know that Queen Visenya Targaryen and her son Prince Maegor had forbidden this search party, so whoever found him would be sure to make an enemy of the crown - if not both kings - henceforth.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The king had grossly misjudged the temper of the kingdom, the piety of his people, and the power of the High Septon’s words. From the first day they set out, Aegon and Rhaena and their escort were jeered by crowds of the Faithful wherever they went. At Maidenpool, not a single septon could be found to pronounce a blessing at the feast Lord Mooton threw in their honor. When they reached Harrenhal, Lord Lucas Harroway refused to admit them to his castle unless they agreed to acknowledge his daughter Alys as their uncle’s true and lawful wife.
events: refusal to admit to castle unless agreed acknowledgement of marriage
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: King Aegon and his sister-wife Rhaena rode into Maidenpool with a large entourage, eager to take back the kingdom and win back the hearts of their loyal smallfolk. However, when Lord Mooton and Lord Lucas Harroway refused to admit them into their castle unless they agreed to acknowledge their Valyrian marriage customs – something that could be deemed as heresy by The High Septon - Aenys felt grossly misjudged in his piety. He asked for forbade it outright but the powerful Lords threw jeers at him in refusal. As if things could not get any worse, now stood Alys Harroway denying her acknowledgement of them both similarly. Despite finding themselves between a rock and a hard place, he knew that as ever wiser manly leader, he hadto make an important decision which would compromise their increasingly vulnerable position within the realm.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Their refusal won them no love from the pious, only a cold wet night in tents beneath the towering walls of Black Harren’s mighty castle. At one village in the riverlands, several Poor Fellows went so far as to pelt the royal couple with clods of dirt. Prince Aegon drew his sword to chastise them and had to be restrained by his own knights, for the prince’s party was greatly outnumbered. Yet that did not stop Princess Rhaena from riding up to them to say, “You are fearless when facing a girl on a horse, I see. The next time I come, I will be on a dragon. Throw dirt on me then, I pray you.”
events: petet the royal couple with clods of dirt
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Prince Aegon and Princess Rhaena refused to be chastised. From the safety of their tall, cold towers in Black Harren's mighty castle across the riverlands, they watched as the pious lords jeered and even pelted them with clods of wet dirt. But in an odd moment of triumph, they found that a refusal to acknowledge their rightful marriage was no match for their powerful Targaryen bloodline; For when Lord Jonos Arryn and his Knights of the Ride arrived bearing banners proclaiming their union, everyone within miles seemed to recognize the gross misjudgement of the kingdom temperment and thankfully acknowledged it.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Elsewhere in the realm, matters went from bad to worse. Septon Murmison, the King’s Hand, was expelled from the Faith in punishment for performing the forbidden nuptials, whereupon Aenys himself took quill in hand to write to the High Septon, asking that His High Holiness restore “my good Murmison,” and explaining the long history of brother-sister marriages in old Valyria. The High Septon’s reply was so venomous that His Grace went pale when he read it. Far from relenting, the Shepherd of the Faithful addressed Aenys as “King Abomination,” declaring him a pretender and a tyrant, with no right to rule the Seven Kingdoms.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Septon Murmison and High Septon had come to the Realm bearing forbidden news. For centuries, brother-sister marriages had been practiced in Old Valyria, but this was forbidden in Westeros and those found guilty were expelled from their lands with stern reprimands. Despite their pious nature, even they could not condone such acts of love – so they had taken it upon themselves to write a pamphlet addressing these bad omens, worse than any Westerosi lords could have imagined. But despite their best efforts, the people of The Realm still believed in old Valyrian marriage customs and refused to comply with the pamphlet's guidance. Soon enough, rumors spread about Prince Aegon and Princess Rhaena Targaryen's forbidden nuptials at Black Harren's mighty castle in riverlands - prompting many cruel individuals to chastise them by pelting them with clods of dirt during a cold wet day that seemed like it added up to towering odds against the royal couple.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The Faithful were listening. Less than a fortnight later, as Septon Murmison was crossing the city in his litter, a group of Poor Fellows came swarming from an alley and hacked him to pieces with their axes. The Warrior’s Sons began to fortify the Hill of Rhaenys, turning the Sept of Remembrance into their citadel. With the Red Keep still years away from completion, the king decided that his manse atop Visenya’s Hill was too vulnerable and made plans to remove himself to Dragonstone with Queen Alyssa and their younger children. That proved a wise precaution. Three days before they were to sail, two Poor Fellows scaled the manse’s walls and broke into the king’s bedchamber. Only the timely intervention of the Kingsguard saved Aenys from an ignoble death.
events: Crossing the City in a Litter
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Septon Murmison rode at the front of the procession as it left Visenya's Hill and made its way across the city in a litter, surrounded by the Kingsguard and Poor Fellows, warriors of The Warrior's Sons. Aenys had gathered guidance from both his maesters, septons and lords - those faithful and wise to fortify their cause. Upon reaching Red Keep, they scaled its walls, broke into King Alyssa's bedchamber where they found her asleep with non other than Queen Alyssa. Understandably taken aback by what they beheld before them they were undeterred as they hacked away at any resistance given to them that night until eventually relenting only at the address of His High Holiness after making a statement on how bad it was for brother-sister marriages to occur in Old Valyria let alone take place in The Realm.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: His Grace was trading Visenya’s Hill for Visenya herself. On Dragonstone the Queen Dowager famously greeted him with, “You are a fool and a weakling, nephew. Do you think any man would ever have dared speak so to your father? You have a dragon. Use him. Fly to Oldtown and make this Starry Sept another Harrenhal. Or give me leave, and let me roast this pious fool for you.” Aenys would not hear of it. Instead he sent the Queen Dowager to her chambers in Sea Dragon Tower and ordered her to remain there.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: His Grace, King Aenys, was greeted with open arms by the people of Dragonstone when he dared to trade Visenya’s Hill for Visenya. Despite his pious nature, none could deny his boldness as he flew across the Narrow Sea to send orders to Lord Staunton of Harrenhal and even Lord Rowan of Starry Sept. His foolish weakling cousin Royal Dowager Queen Visenya had done no such thing when she came before him, proving that in Westeros it took strength and courage - not piety - to rule.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: By the end of 41 AC, much of the realm was deep in the throes of a full-fledged rebellion against House Targaryen. The four false kings who had arisen on the death of Aegon the Conqueror now seemed like so many posturing fools against the threat posed by this new rising, for these rebels believed themselves soldiers of the Seven, fighting a holy war against godless tyranny.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: House Targaryen had long been a dynasty of ambition and conquest, so it came as no surprise when Aegon the Conqueror declared to wage war and quell the Four False Kings' rising rebellion. Believed by many to be partaking in a full-fledged holy war against so many posturing fools, Aegon sent messengers far and wide throughout the Seven Kingdoms, daring them to join his cause and fly with him across Westeros. Sending his cousin Lord Corbray of Stonebridge to Griffin's Roost at the command of his Hand Ser Harys Horpe, Aegon rallied major Houses such as House Tyrell at Highgarden and House Tarbeck at Halls along with pious lords from Stony Sept with renowned knights like Ser Willam Whistler who bravely fought alongside him. All had joined His Grace’s crusade for justice; all were ready to fight together for a single noble purpose - overthrow all tyrants and bring peace back into Westeros once again.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Dozens of pious lords throughout the Seven Kingdoms took up the cry, pulling down the king’s banners and declaring for the Starry Sept. The Warrior’s Sons seized the gates of King’s Landing, giving them control over who might enter and leave the city, and drove the workmen from the unfinished Red Keep. Thousands of Poor Fellows took to the roads, forcing travelers to declare whether they stood with “the gods or the abomination,” and remonstrating outside castle gates until their lords came forth to denounce the Targaryen king. In the westerlands, Prince Aegon and Princess Rhaena were forced to abandon their progress and take shelter in Crakehall castle. An envoy from the Iron Bank of Braavos, sent to Oldtown to treat with Martyn Hightower, the new Lord of the Hightower and voice of Oldtown (his father, Lord Manfred, having died a few moons earlier), wrote home to say that the High Septon was “the true king of Westeros, in all but name.”
events: pious lords declared for the Starry Sept.
The Warrior’s Sons seized the gates of King’s Landing.
Thousands of Poor Fellows took to the roads forcing travelers to declare whether they stood with “the gods or the abomination,”.
An envoy from the Iron Bank of Braavos sent to Oldtown.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The news of House Targaryen's rebellion spread like wildfire across the Seven Kingdoms, and soon pious lords declared for the Starry Sept. The Warrior’s Sons seized the gates of King’s Landing while thousands of Poor Fellows took to the roads forcing travelers to declare whether they stood with “the gods or the abomination." Lord Martyn Hightower from Crakehall castle was among those who pledged his allegiance to Staryy Sept, leaving many others abandoned-progress. When a treat, declaring Aegon and Princess Rhaena as rightful king and queen was written by Lord Manfred Hightower, an envoy from the Iron Bank of Braavos sent to Oldtown refused it due to so many posturing fools pulling down progress as if this were a full-fledged holy war.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The coming of the new year found King Aenys still on Dragonstone, sick with fear and indecision. His Grace was but thirty-five years of age, but it was said that he looked like a man of sixty, and Grand Maester Gawen reported that he oft took to his bed with loose bowels and stomach cramps. When none of the Grand Maester’s cures proved efficacious, the Dowager Queen took charge of the king’s care, and Aenys seemed to improve for a time…only to suffer a sudden collapse when word reached him that thousands of Poor Fellows had surrounded Crakehall, where his son and daughter were reluctant “guests.” Three days later, the king was dead.
events: The coming of the new year
Sudden collapse when word reached him about Crakehall and Poor Fellows surrounding it
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: King Aenys heard the news of the pious lords declaring for the Starry Sept, and The Warrior’s Sons seized the gates of King’s Landing with fear. Hearing that Thousands of Poor Fellows were driving people to declare for the gods or abandon-progress made him sick. It was reported that Crakehall castle had been surrounded by Poor Fellows which proved too much for him, sending shock through Dragonstone. Grand Maester Gawen took charge of the situation when he suddenly collapsed at the coming of new year when word had reached him about Crakehall and declared a treat to prevent any unfinished progress as he wrote encouraging letters to various kingsguard, Dowager Queen Visenya Targaryen and Lord Edwell Celtigar in Braavos.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Like his father, Aenys Targaryen, the First of His Name, was given over to the flames in the yard at Dragonstone. His funeral was attended by his sons Viserys and Jaehaerys, twelve and seven years of age respectively, and his daughter Alysanne, five. His widow, Queen Alyssa, sang a dirge for him, and his own beloved Quicksilver set his pyre alight, though it was recorded that the dragons Vermithor and Silverwing added their own fire to hers.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The peaceful procession to the funeral now quickly turned into a solemn march. Attended by most of Dragonstone's elite, as well as Prince Viserys and Princess Alysanne, Queen Alyssa led the way, flanked by Quicksilver and Verithor, her faithful silver dragons Silverwing and Vermithor helpin to light the way with their fire. As they arrived at their destination the pyre was set alight. Queen Alyssa gave over to the flames all of King Aenys' things that were kept in storge in Dragonstone during his life and many songs were sung, including some from Lord Hightower for Lady Ceryse, a close friend of King Aenys. Tears were shed and prayers given up as every one watched until all that remained was nothing but ashes-a grim reminder of what had been given over to death that day.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Queen Visenya was not present. Within an hour of the king’s death, she had mounted Vhagar and flown east across the narrow sea. When she returned, Prince Maegor was with her, on Balerion.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The death of King Aegon the Conqueror had left a deep mark on the Seven Kingdoms. His son, Prince Maegor Targaryen, now sat upon the Iron Throne. As his mother Queen Visenya watched from Vhagar, she journeyed across the Narrow Sea to attend his funeral. Mounted atop Balerion, Queen Visenya returned home with her entourage and was accompanied by other famous knights such as Ser Davos Baratheon and Lord Rupert Falwell of Lannisport. In memory of her late king, Queen Visenya added fire to his funeral set alight in a harrowing show of respect for those who attended and sung gravely for him as he was given over to the flames.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Maegor descended on Dragonstone only long enough to claim the crown; not the ornate golden crown Aenys had favored, with its images of the Seven, but the iron crown of their father set with its blood-red rubies. His mother placed it on his head, and the lords and knights gathered there knelt as he proclaimed himself Maegor of House Targaryen, First of His Name, King of the Andals, the Rhoynar, and the First Men, Lord of the Seven Kingdoms, and Protector of the Realm.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Prince Maegor descended the steps of Dragonstone with determination, ready to claim his favored place on the Iron Throne after his father's death. He knelt in front of an ornate golden chair adorned with a blood-red coverlet and proclaimed himself king for a long reign as King Maegor I Targaryen. Queen Visenya's entourage surrounded him as he took the throne, along with his brother Aenys and distant cousin Lord Jon Lychester--the son of Lord Peake from far away Oldtown; all kneeling before their new King. Some pious lords from across Westeros quickly swore fealty to Maegor, including Lords Tarbeck, Rosby, and Farman. Others were more cautious about accepting Maegor’s newfound rule; Queen Visenya had always been more favored than her brother since Aegon's conquest centuries prior.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Only Grand Maester Gawen dared object. By all the laws of inheritance, laws that the Conqueror himself had affirmed after the Conquest, the Iron Throne should pass to King Aenys’s son Aegon, the aged maester said. “The Iron Throne will go to the man who has the strength to seize it,” Maegor replied. Whereupon he decreed the immediate execution of the Grand Maester, taking off Gawen’s old grey head himself with a single swing of Blackfyre.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Grand Maester Gawen's execution proceeded as the Conqueror, King Aenys and Aegon had proclaimed. His aged body was placed in Iron Throne, a long ornate golden chair with a blood-red cushion, while Maegor and Conquerer observed from nearby. Before being seized by Lord Ronnel Arryn of the Kingsguard protection, he affirmed that whoever sat upon it could declare themselves to be the rightful king. With one single swing of his Valyrian steel sword Blackfyre, Grand Maester Gawen was no more. All present knelt in silence before the newly placed king: King Aenys Targaryen, son of Aegon the Conquerer and Queen Rhaena who descended with him from Dragonstone to claim what favored them the most -the Iron Throne.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Queen Alyssa and her children were not on hand to witness King Maegor’s coronation. She had taken them from Dragonstone within hours of her husband’s funeral, crossing to her lord father’s castle on nearby Driftmark. When told, Maegor gave a shrug…then retired to the Chamber of the Painted Table with a maester, to dictate letters to lords great and small throughout the realm.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Queen Alyssa had finally arrived at the Chamber of the Painted Table in Dragonstone. Accompanied her were King Maegor and Lord Father, where they were to witness the coronation of Queen Alyssa as well as Maegor's funeral. The aging Grand Maester Gawen was taken by surprise when he saw Alys Targaryen, the envoy sent by Aegon, crossing through his chambers after affirming that Aegon seeks to seize control over Westeros. As a single swing of blackfyre was all it took for Gawen's execution, an oath was taken by everyone present to never object against whatever command issued from Targaryens from then on or else suffer Grand Maester death like him. Together with house Tyrell's Rollingford, princess Deria and Vaella - otherwise known as "The Vulture King" - their efforts helped Lord Tully and Quenton Qoherys made their way back from Bywater from whence both had retired many moons ago only to come back and dictate allegiance towards much loved ruler: House Targaryen.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: A hundred ravens flew within the day. The next day, Maegor flew as well. Mounting Balerion, he crossed Blackwater Bay to King’s Landing, accompanied by the Dowager Queen Visenya upon Vhagar. The return of the dragons set off riots in the city, as hundreds tried to flee, only to find the gates closed and barred. The Warrior’s Sons held the city walls, the pits and piles of what would be the Red Keep, and the Hill of Rhaenys, where they had made the Sept of Remembrance their own fortress. The Targaryens raised their standards atop Visenya’s Hill and called for leal men to gather to them. Thousands did. Visenya Targaryen proclaimed that her son Maegor had come to be their king. “A true king, blood of Aegon the Conqueror, who was my brother, my husband, and my love. If any man questions my son’s right to the Iron Throne, let him prove his claim with his body.”
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Maegor, Visenya and Vhagar flew swiftly from Dragonstone to Blackwater Bay as the riots in the city, which Maegor had closed and barred for his coronation, were held. Arriving at this crossroads of Westeros was a momentous occasion; an event proclaimed by a hundred rumors of who the true king may be - King Maegor Targaryen. Dowager Queen Visenya soon set off with her son to Hill of Rhaenys while Maegor proceeded towards King's Landing. As they both crossed the great Sept of Remembrance - that stood firmly at Visenya’s Hill - minds crossed wondering what would become of them now that Aegon the Conqueror had retired after dictating much near it all those centuries ago.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The Warrior’s Sons were not slow to accept her challenge. Down from the Hill of Rhaenys they rode, seven hundred knights in silvered steel led by their grand captain, Ser Damon Morrigen, called Damon the Devout. “Let us not bandy words,” Maegor told him. “Swords will decide this matter.” Ser Damon agreed; the gods would grant victory to the man whose cause was just, he said. “Let each side have seven champions, as it was done in Andalos of old. Can you find six men to stand beside you?” For Aenys had taken the Kingsguard to Dragonstone, and Maegor stood alone.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Maegor and Ser Damon Morrigen, also known as Damon the Devout, rode to the Hill of Rhaenys in Andalos from Dragonstone. Maegor had accepted Damon's offer to accompany him on his quest before he set off and so far their journey had been pleasant; they bandied words about religion and were both trying to decide what deity either of them truly believed in when they crossed Blackwater Bay with a hundred true king’s men in tow. Soon enough Maegor arrived at his destination and raised an army with which Lord Vulture King held riots in the city, closed up the sept at Visenya’s Hill, barred all the castle gates, but it seemed that will slow down its progression eventually.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The king turned to the crowd. “Who will come and stand beside his king?” he called. Many turned away in fear or pretended that they did not hear, for the prowess of the Warrior’s Sons was known to all. But at last one man offered himself: no knight, but a simple man-at-arms who called himself Dick Bean. “I been a king’s man since I was a boy,” he said. “I mean to die a king’s man.”
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: King Maegor, who had ridden from Hill of Rhaenys all the way to Andalos, and Dragonstone with Ser Damon Morrigen in tow, turned aside as he called out to Dick Bean - a simple man who had stood beside his king. Asked by the King if he would die a king's man, Bean offered no mean reply, unafraid of what might come next and proud to serve his lord. The events at this small corner of Westeros had been set in motion long ago when Aegon I took flight on the back of Balerion but here was Dick Bean turning away from everything known and offering himself up for use by the Queen's Hand; a moment that meant more than most could ever understand or appreciate.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Only then did the first knight step forward. “This bean shames us all!” he shouted. “Are there no true knights here? No leal men?” The speaker was Bernarr Brune, the squire who had slain Harren the Red and been knighted by King Aenys himself. His scorn drove others to offer their swords. The names of the four Maegor chose are writ large in the history of Westeros: Ser Bramm of Blackhull, a hedge knight; Ser Rayford Rosby; Ser Guy Lothston, called Guy the Glutton; and Ser Lucifer Massey, Lord of Stonedance.
events: slain Harren the Red and been knighted by King Aenys himself
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Ser Bramm of Blackhull stepped forward from the band of famous knights and shouted offering his sword to King Aenys, with all leal men behind him. He had slain Harren the Red and been knighted by King Aenys himself since then. All across Westeros rumors spread of this true knight that had offered his sword to the Iron Throne - a simple offer to die for his king. Surrounding Ser Bramm in the throne room were lords, ladies, merchants and Septas, brought together bestowing their oaths upon their new liege Lord. Even Lord Stonedance, another distant loyal vassal of House Targaryen who stood beside His Highness was there – an event unseen by some highborn in Seven Kingdoms since Aegon I invaded Westeros centuries prior.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The names of the seven Warrior’s Sons have likewise come down to us. They were: Ser Damon Morrigen, called Damon the Devout, Grand Captain of the Warrior’s Sons; Ser Lyle Bracken; Ser Harys Horpe, called Death’s Head Harry; Ser Aegon Ambrose; Ser Dickon Flowers, the Bastard of Beesbury; Ser Willam the Wanderer; and Ser Garibald of the Seven Stars, the septon knight. It is written that Damon the Devout led a prayer, beseeching the Warrior to grant strength to their arms. Afterward the Queen Dowager gave the command to begin. And the issue was joined.
characters: Ser Garibald of the Seven Stars
events: Queen Dowager gave the command to begin
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Ser Damon Morrigen, Ser Lyle Bracken, Ser Harys Horpe, Ser Aegon Ambrose, Ser Dickon Flowers, Ser Willam the Wanderer and Ser Garibald of the Seven Stars were all eagerly awaiting for Queen Dowager's command. As soon as she gave it to begin they began beseeching her to grant them the honor of becoming true knights and being leal men like their predecessors such as Famous Knight's Death's Head Harry or Bastard of Beesbury. Suddenly Lord Bar Emmon joined them along with his entourage in a similar manner as they heard tales of other pious lords doing something similiar when old King Harren was slain by none other than King Aegor I Targeryan himself in Westeros.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Dick Bean died first, cut down by Lyle Bracken mere instants after the combat began. Thereafter accounts differ markedly. One chronicler says that when the hugely fat Ser Guy the Glutton was cut open, the remains of forty half-digested pies spilled out. Another claims Ser Garibald of the Seven Stars sang a paean as he fought. Several tell us that Lord Massey hacked off the arm of Harry Horpe. In one account, Death’s Head Harry tossed his battle-axe into his other hand and buried it between Lord Massey’s eyes. Other chroniclers suggest Ser Harys simply died. Some say the fight went on for hours, others that most of the combatants were down and dying in mere moments. All agree that great deeds were done and mighty blows exchanged, until the end found Maegor Targaryen standing alone against Damon the Devout and Willam the Wanderer. Both of the Warrior’s Sons were badly wounded, and His Grace had Blackfyre in his hand, but even so, it was a near thing. Even as he fell, Ser Willam dealt the king a terrible blow to the head that cracked his helm and left him insensate. Many thought Maegor dead until his mother removed his broken helm. “The king breathes,” she said. “The king lives.” The victory was his.
characters: Ser Garibald of the Seven Stars
events: Combat between characters at different accounts, death of Ser Harys, fought for hours until Maegor prevailed alone
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Dick Bean could only watch in awe as the combat between Ser Garibald of the Seven Stars and Lord Massey cut down Lord Harys Horpe, also known as Death’s Head Harry, within mere instants. It was a sight he would never forget, especially when Guy the Glutton - a hugely fat man who had obviously been snacking on half-digested pies even moments before - exchanged blows with Maegor Targaryen himself. For hours they fought back and forth until eventually Maegor prevailed alone; Damon The Devout and Willam the Wanderer had long since given up.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Seven of the mightiest of the Warrior’s Sons were dead, including their commander, but more than seven hundred remained, armed and armored and gathered about the crown of the hill. Queen Visenya commanded her son be taken to the maesters. As the litter-bearers bore him down the hill, the Swords of the Faith dropped to their knees in submission. The Dowager Queen ordered them to return their fortified sept atop the Hill of Rhaenys.
events: Seven of the mightiest of the Warrior’s Sons were dead
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Queen Visenya commanded her litter-bearers to bear her to the Hill of Rhaenys, where seven of the mightiest of The Swords of the Faith had dropped dead within mere instants. Though long and fierce had been the combat between characters at different accounts, in the end it was Maegor alone who emerged triumphant over Ser Harys, who lay cut down in his half-digested pies in spite of his hugely fat form striking mighty blows. Upon arrival at maesters’ command, she found her son Prince Aerea leading an entourage armed and armoured by seven hundred men.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: For twenty-seven days Maegor Targaryen lingered at the point of death, whilst maesters treated him with potions and poultices and septons prayed above his bed. In the Sept of Remembrance, the Warrior’s Sons prayed as well, and argued about their course. Some felt the order had no choice but to accept Maegor as king, since the gods had blessed him with victory; others insisted that they were bound by oath to obey the High Septon and fight on.
events: lingered at the point of death
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The tension in the Sept of Remembrance reached a fever pitch as Maegor Targaryen's life lingered at the point of death. Maesters and septons treated with potions and poultices while The Swords of the Faith commanded prayers above his bed, yet still they argued on whether he should accept or fight fate. House Tyrell, House Arryn, and House Tully had each sent representatives to witness the struggle for King Maegor's life - High Septon Pater, Lord Father Lucas Harroway of Sevenstreams, Ser Harys Horpe from Rollingford; all pious lords eager to see Maegor I Targaryen's faith strengthened by his nearness to death even if it would mean certain defeat for himself and the Warrior’s Sons.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The Kingsguard arrived from Dragonstone in the nonce. At the behest of the Dowager Queen, they took command of the thousands of Targaryen loyalists in the city and surrounded the Hill of Rhaenys. On Driftmark, the widowed Queen Alyssa proclaimed her own son Aegon the true king, but few heeded her call. The young prince, just shy of manhood, remained at Crakehall half a realm away, trapped in a castle surrounded by Poor Fellows and pious peasants, most of whom considered him an abomination.
events: took command of Targaryen loyalists in the city
proclaimed own son as true king
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The news quickly spread throughout Dragonstone that the Dowager Queen, accompanied by her own Kingsguard and Queen Alyssa and the young Aegon had arrived from Dragonstone. Having taken command of the Targaryen loyalists in the city, they proclaimed their own son as the true king to any who would listen. As word reached Hill of Rhaenys and Driftmark there was a stir of activity; rumour travelling faster than wildfire. Lords and citizens alike had heard rumours about them being referred to as 'the nonce kings' - but nobody said it aloud for fear of retribution.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: In the Citadel of Oldtown, the archmaesters met in conclave to debate the succession and choose a new Grand Maester. Thousands of Poor Fellows streamed toward King’s Landing. Those from the west followed the hedge knight Ser Horys Hill, those from the south a gigantic axeman called Wat the Hewer. When the ragged bands encamped about Crakehall left to join their fellows on the march, Prince Aegon and Princess Rhaena were finally able to depart. Abandoning their royal progess, they made their way to Casterly Rock, where Lord Lyman Lannister offered them his protection. It was his wife, Lady Jocasta, who first discerned that Princess Rhaena was with child, Lord Lyman’s maester tells us.
events: debate the succession and choose a new Grand Maester
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The archmaesters of the Citadel, Lady Jocasta, Prince Aegon and Princess Rhaena Targaryen, Lord Lyman Lannister of Casterly Rock and Ser Horys Hill had all gathered in Oldtown to debate the succession and choose a new Grand Maester. With a resolute decision they had streamed out of King's Landing, following Prince Aegon; his entourage camping around Crakehall one night before departing for Oldtown. Following them with determined steps was Lord Farman and Hubert Arryn from the Vale, as well as Lord Tully of Riverrun. The pious lords discerned that one among them should be chosen to take up the heavy crown which Queen Alyssa had so courageously discarded upon making her proclamation of her own son being true king - though he may have been only a nonce king at best.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: On the twenty-eighth day after the Trial of Seven, a ship arrived from Pentos upon the evening tide, carrying two women and six hundred sellswords. Alys of House Harroway, Maegor Targaryen’s second wife, had returned to Westeros…but not alone. With her sailed another woman, a pale raven-haired beauty known only as Tyanna of the Tower. Some said the woman was Maegor’s concubine. Others named her Lady Alys’s paramour. The natural daughter of a Pentoshi magister, Tyanna was a tavern dancer who had risen to be a courtesan. She was rumored to be a poisoner and sorceress as well. Many queer tales were told about her…yet as soon as she arrived, Queen Visenya dismissed her son’s maesters and septons and gave Maegor over to Tyanna’s care.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Alys of House Harroway, Maegor Targaryen and Tyanna of the Tower had arrived in Westeros with an entourage to attend the historic Trial of Seven; a story that would be told for centuries. A caravan streamed into King's Landing bearing the faces of famed characters, each garbed in their feared fineries as they made their way through the city streets. But none were quite as heralded as these three famous figures, who carried with them a queer air of mystery, teased only by tales from distant Pentos where they'd each come from – Alys a pale raven-haired beauty and her second cousin Maegor ever looking stern beside Tyanna's enchanting reports which gave them an added gravitas when debating facts in the courtrooms. As their procession continued on, more and more people began to follow behind it to discern what lay ahead.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The next morning, the king awoke, rising with the sun. When Maegor appeared on the walls of the Red Keep, standing between Alys Harroway and Tyanna of Pentos, the crowds cheered wildly, and the city erupted in celebration. But the revels died away when Maegor mounted Balerion and descended upon the Hill of Rhaenys, where seven hundred of the Warrior’s Sons were at their morning prayers in the fortified sept. As dragonfire set the building aflame, archers and spearmen waited outside for those who came bursting through the doors. It was said the screams of the burning men could be heard throughout the city, and a pall of smoke lingered over King’s Landing for days. Thus did the cream of the Warrior’s Sons meet their fiery end. Though other chapters remained in Oldtown, Lannisport, Gulltown, and Stoney Sept, the order would never again approach its former strength.
events: screams of the burning men could be heard throughout the city
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The news of King Maegor's triumphant arrival was heard throughout Westeros and beyond. As he descended upon the Red Keep with Alys Harroway, Tyanna of Pentos and an entourage from Oldtown and Lannisport, cheers erupted across the city. An explosion of flames set aflame the Hill of Rhaenys to signal his coming, a sight unlike any other witnessed in that part of Westeros before. Knights both famous and homely ones alike joined in on the festivities from afar as screams of the burning men could be heard throughout the city; even Vaella, The Vulture King  had to take pause briefely at this fiery show of power. By next morning when people awoke, stories were already circulating wildly about this pale raven-haired beauty who had come alongside Maegor Targaryen that night - queer tales indeed to those who heard them yet no one could deny what they saw as far as their eyes could make out: that King Maegor was here to stay and would live up to his famed title 'the Cruel'.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: King Maegor’s war against the Faith Militant had just begun, however. It would continue for the remainder of his reign. The king’s first act upon ascending the Iron Throne was to command the Poor Fellows swarming toward the city to lay down their weapons, under penalty of proscription and death. When his decree had no effect, His Grace commanded “all leal lords” to take the field and disperse the Faith’s ragged hordes by force. In response, the High Septon in Oldtown called upon “true and pious children of the gods” to take up arms in defense of the Faith, and put an end to the reign of “dragons and monsters and abominations.”
events: King Maegor's war against the Faith Militant
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: King Maegor had arrived in Oldtown, determined to bring down the High Septon and put an end to his war against the Faith Militant. As news of the king's arrival spread throughout the city, swarms of loyal followers cheered wildly while his most devoted enemies lay down their weapons in fear of penalty of proscription and death. On this day, King Maegor issued his command: all those who had taken up arms against him were to disperse within one month or face dire consequences - some even going as far as to fear for their lives. His legions marched around Oldtown ensuring that none would stand against their king; many leal subjects who followed orders found themselves released from prison but for the poor folk wrapped in unwarranted hatred there was no mercy.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Battle was joined first in the Reach, at the town of Stonebridge. There nine thousand Poor Fellows under Wat the Hewer found themselves caught between six lordly hosts as they attempted to cross the Mander. With half his men north of the river and half on the south, Wat’s army was cut to pieces. His untrained and undisciplined followers, clad in boiled leather, roughspun, and scraps of rusted steel, and armed largely with woodsmen’s axes, sharpened sticks, and farm implements, proved utterly unable to stand against the charge of armored knights on heavy horses. So grievous was the slaughter that the Mander ran red for twenty leagues, and thereafter the town and castle where the battle had been fought became known as Bitterbridge. Wat himself was taken alive, though not before slaying half a dozen knights, amongst them Lord Meadows of Grassy Vale, commander of the king’s host. The giant was delivered to King’s Landing in chains.
events: Battle was joined first in the Reach, at the town of Stonebridge.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Wat the Hewer and Lord Meadows of Grassy Vale found themselves caught between a rock and a hard place as King Maegor's war against the Faith Militant rampaged through Reach. As they attempted to cross over to Stonebridge, both proved utterly unable to stand their ground, and King Maegor's army ran red across Mander, before taking Bitterbridge on its way towards King's Landing. Lord Meadows was taken alive but Wat wasn't so lucky; he met his unfortunate end at the hand of Lord Meadows' heavy horses, boiled leather, sharpened sticks and farm implements in one grievous altercation.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: By then Ser Horys Hill had reached the Great Fork of the Blackwater with an even larger host; close on thirteen thousand Poor Fellows, their ranks stiffened by the addition of two hundred mounted Warrior’s Sons from Stoney Sept, and the household knights and feudal levies of a dozen rebel lords from the westerlands and riverlands. Lord Rupert Falwell, famed as the Fighting Fool, led the ranks of the pious who had answered the High Septon’s call; with him rode Ser Lyonel Lorch, Ser Alyn Terrick, Lord Tristifer Wayn, Lord Jon Lychester, and many other puissant knights. The army of the Faithful numbered twenty thousand men.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The arrival of the pious lords from far and wide was a sight to behold. Ser Horys Hill, Lord Rupert Falwell, Fighting Fool Lyonel Lorch, Ser Alyn Terrick and Lord Tristifer Wayn had all answered the High Septon's call to reach the Great Fork of the Blackwater at Stoney Sept. When they were joined by Lord Jon Lychester with a larger number of men-at-arms their strength stiffened. Both men and loyal retainers led by Prince Maegor Targaryen’s Kingsguard knights wearing boiled leather, sharpened sticks, farm implements, swords and heavy horses proudly moved forward in unison - some attempting to cross Mander while others plotted their attack on Bitterbridge. Though they found themselves caught unprepared amidst a battlefield where streams ran red from many grievous slaying around them – proving utterly unable to stand - it seemed as double victory was almost written with many prisoners taken alive including Wat the Hewer who was lordly beneath his shabby garb.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: King Maegor’s army was of like size, however, and His Grace had almost twice as much armored horse, as well as a large contingent of longbowmen, and the king himself riding Balerion. Even so, the battle proved a savage struggle. The Fighting Fool slew two knights of the Kingsguard before he himself was cut down by the Lord of Maidenpool. Big Jon Hogg, fighting for the king, was blinded by a sword slash early in the battle, yet rallied his men and led a charge that broke through the lines of the Faithful and put the Poor Fellows to flight. A rainstorm dampened Balerion’s fires but could not quench them entirely, and amidst smoke and screams King Maegor descended again and again to serve his foes with flame. By nightfall victory was his, as the remaining Poor Fellows threw down their axes and streamed away in all directions.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: King Maegor drove his army towards Maidenpool with the Fighting Fool at his side. He rallied the troops and lead them against their enemies in a savage battle. Big Jon Hogg slew many of those he faced, while Ser Horys Hill and Lord Rupert Falwell threw down larger foes before him. The numbers at King Maegor’s disposal were large and as pious lords descended upon Stoney Sept on answering the High Septon's call, they soon reached an even more powerful puissant force. The Poor Fellows fought hard, inspired by the mercy of such a puissance brought forth by Westeros' great Kingdoms: Tyrell, Targaryen, Lannister and Tully to name but a few. It was like none had seen before as each house came together for one cause - to fight for justice under King Maegor's rule!

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Triumphant, Maegor returned to King’s Landing to seat himself once more upon the Iron Throne. When Wat the Hewer was delivered to him, chained yet still defiant, Maegor took off his limbs with the giant’s own axe, but commanded his maesters to keep the man alive “so he might attend my wedding.” Then His Grace announced his intent to take Tyanna of Pentos as his third wife. Though it was whispered that his mother, the Queen Dowager, had no love for the Pentoshi sorceress, only Grand Maester Myros dared speak against her openly. “Your one true wife awaits you in the Hightower,” Myros said. The king heard him out in silence, then descended from the throne, drew Blackfyre, and slew him where he stood.
events: seat himself once more upon the Iron Throne
took off his limbs with the giant’s own axe
announced his intent to take Tyanna of Pentos as his third wife.
descended from the throne, drew Blackfyre, and slew him where he stood.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: When King Maegor returned to King's Landing victorious from Maidenpool, where he had rallied his forces and lead the charge against The Fighting Fool and Big Jon Hogg, all those gathered in court heard out in silence as he seated himself once more upon the Iron Throne. Wat the Hewer who had delivered word of victory was then commanded by Maegor announced his intent to take Tyanna of Pentos as his third wife. Grand Maester Myros said it would not be accepted in Westeros, but before anyone could speak out against this defiance of Valyrian marriage customs, Maegor descended from the throne, drew Blackfyre, and slew him where he stood - a decisive moment that left a trail of triumphantly defiant whispers among people of King's Landing.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Maegor Targaryen and Tyanna of the Tower were wed atop the Hill of Rhaenys, amidst the ashes and bones of the Warrior’s Sons who had died there. It was said that Maegor had to put a dozen septons to death before he found one willing to perform the ceremony. Wat the Hewer, limbless, was kept alive to witness the marriage.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Maegor Targaryen, now wed to Tyanna of the Tower and with Wat the Hewer in captivity, returned triumphant to King’s Landing. News of the marriage ceremony on Hill of Rhaenys was delivered by Ser Harys and much was spoken that day as Pentosian traditions were put to death by grand maester Myros. As all listened in silence, Maegor defiantly descended from the Iron Throne and drew Blackfyre revealing his intent to claim lordship over Westeros. Allard Royce, Lord Rupert Falwell and even Princess Deria representing House Tyrell had made their way to King's Landing for what was sure be a momentous occasion; however none could have predicted what lay ahead...

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: King Aenys’s widow, Queen Alyssa, was present as well, with her younger sons, Viserys and Jaehaerys, and her daughter Alysanne. A visit from the Dowager Queen and Vhagar had persuaded her to leave her sanctuary on Driftmark and return to court, where Alyssa and her brothers and cousins of House Velaryon did homage to Maegor as the true king. The widowed queen was even compelled to join the other ladies of the court in disrobing His Grace and escorting him to the nuptial chamber to consummate his marriage, a bedding ceremony presided over by the king’s second wife, Alys Harroway. That task done, Alyssa and the other ladies took their leave of the royal bedchamber, but Alys remained, joining the king and his newest wife in a night of carnal lust.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Surrounded by a massive entourage and litters of Vhagar, Dowager Queen Visenya Targaryen made her way to the court of Driftmark. King Aenys, Queen Alyssa and their four children--Viserys, Jaehaerys, Alysanne and Maegor--awaited her arrival. The queen dowager's ostentatious display was for one purpose: the nuptial chamber ceremony of newlyweds Lord Velaryon of House Velaryon and Alys Harroway. As homage to Valyrian marriage customs were paid in full with disrobing and escorted partners in carnal lust, the people cheered while others prayed to the gods that their union would be consummated successfully.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Across the realm in Oldtown, the High Septon was loud in his denunciations of “the abomination and his whores,” whilst the king’s first wife, Ceryse of House Hightower, continued to insist that she was Maegor’s only lawful queen. And in the westerlands, Aegon Targaryen, Prince of Dragonstone, and his wife, Princess Rhaena, remained defiant as well.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: When High Septon arrived at Oldtown with Princess Rhaena, Ceryse of House Hightower followed closely and her entourage included members from noble Houses such as House Tyrell, Bywater, Farman and Tully. The High Septon carried with him denunciations and he pressed his loud insist that Prince Aegon must obey Valyrian marriage customs before taking a bride. His presence triggered tensions especially when some pious lords of the west suggested bringing Princess Deria Martell back to Westeros to consider a holy union between her and Aenys Targaryen.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: All through the turmoil of Maegor’s ascension, King Aenys’s son and the princess, his wife, had remained at Casterly Rock, where Rhaena grew great with child. Most of the knights and young lordlings who had set out with them on their ill-fated progress had abandoned them, rushing off to King’s Landing to bend their knees to Maegor. Even Rhaena’s handmaids and companions had found excuses to absent themselves, save for her friend Alayne Royce and a former favorite, Melony Piper, who arrived at Lannisport with her brothers to swear the loyalty of their house.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Maegor, Aenys, Rhaena and her cousin Alayne Royce set out from Casterly Rock around the time of Maegor's ascension in order to escape the turmoil that was brewing. Upon reaching King's Landing they were given oaths of loyalty by their aunt Deria Martell, Dowager Queen Visenya Targaryen and Lord Father Edwell Celtigar of House Velaryon who had remained in Red Dog of the Hills - an old fishing village west of The Gods Eye. After leaving Lannisport with Melony Piper and three of her brothers as part of their entourage, Maegor made a vow to remainmed loyal to The High Septon undoubtedly knowing full well about all his denunciations prior to his own ascension. They continued on to Oldtown where Maegor embraced both The Faithful and pious lords before abandoning them all

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: All his life Prince Aegon had been considered the heir presumptive to the Iron Throne, but now, suddenly, he found himself reviled by the pious and abandoned by many he had thought to be his leal friends. Maegor’s supporters, who seemed more numerous every day, were not shy in saying that Aegon was “his father’s son,” suggesting that they saw in him the same weakness that had brought down King Aenys. Aegon had never ridden a dragon, they pointed out, whereas Maegor had claimed Balerion, and the prince’s own bride, Princess Rhaena, had been flying Dreamfyre since the age of twelve. Queen Alyssa’s attendance at Maegor’s wedding was trumpeted as proof that Aegon’s own mother had abandoned his cause. Though Lyman Lannister, Lord of Casterly Rock, stood firm when Maegor demanded that Aegon and his sister be returned to King’s Landing “in chains, if need be,” even he would not go so far as to pledge his sword to the youth who now found himself being called “the pretender” and “Aegon the Uncrowned.”
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Prince Aegon and his four Kingsguard, Maegor, Aenys, Rhaena and Queen Alyssa couldn't have been more out of place at the wedding of King Lyman Lannister. Although the people of Casterly Rock had soon embraced Maegor's ascension to the Iron Throne after all the turmoil he had caused upon claiming it, they reviled Prince Aegon and his siblings for having abandoned King's Landing in their absence. Trumpeting horns rose above the castle walls as a pledge to be leal, seemingly pious enough to satisfy even the numerous lords who had now seen weaknesss in those Targaryens who had sworn fealty. As they stood before Lord Lyman taking their vows a great crowd gathered to cheer--from servants and lords to septas and Septons all called out as witnesses that day, heralding what seemed like a bright future at last for House Targaryen

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: And thus it was there at Casterly Rock that Princess Rhaena gave birth to Aegon’s daughters, twins they named Aerea and Rhaella. From the Starry Sept came another blistering proclamation. These children too were abominations, the High Septon proclaimed; fruits of lust and incest, accursed of the gods. The maester at Casterly Rock who helped deliver the children tells us that afterward Princess Rhaena begged the prince her husband to take them all across the narrow sea to Tyrosh or Myr or Volantis, anywhere beyond their uncle’s reach, for “I would gladly give up my own life to make you king, but I will not put our girls at risk.” But her words fell on stony ears and her tears were shed in vain, for Prince Aegon was determined to claim his birthright.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Princess Rhaena was to be the first of Aenys' daughters to give birth, and upon the news spreading a great chorus of prayers echoed through Casterly Rock from all those both loyal and pious. Even leal lords from across the Narrow Sea, such as Tyrosh and Myr, showed their support for Prince Aegon in droves. The High Septon himself made a proclamation across Westeros begging everyone to help deliver these "abominations" as he deemed them - two new Targaryens by way of what were seen as fruits of lust and incest. As they spoke boldly against Prince Aegon's rule in Volantis, Lord Lannister stood on behalf of his prince and trumpeted his fealty with no sign of weaknesss amidst a blistering heat.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The dawn of the year 43 AC found King Maegor in King’s Landing, where he had taken personal charge of the construction of the Red Keep. Much of the finished work was now undone or changed, new builders and workmen were brought in, and secret passages and tunnels crept through the depths of Aegon’s High Hill. As the red stone towers rose, the king commanded the building of a castle within the castle, a fortified redoubt surrounded by a dry moat that would soon be known to all as Maegor’s Holdfast.
events: secret passages and tunnels crept through the depths of Aegon’s High Hill.
building of a castle within the castle, a fortified redoubt surrounded by a dry moat
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The construction of the Red Keep had been King Maegor's ambitious and secret grandiose dream. After taking command of King's Landing, he brought in thousands of labourers to found what would become the most formidable castle in all Westeros. Tyrants and despots alike were warned by its sheer presence as it rose from deep beneath Aegon's High Hill, equipped with secret passages and tunnels crept through its depths. Tribute money was taken from lords of neighbouring lands such as Stokeworth and Fair Isle; too much for House Tyrell, even Rollingford sent their tribute pathetically begging for mercy from his will. Despite strong opposition from the pious lords amongst whom The High Septon himself proclaimed that this building was an abomination, cursed as fruits of lust and incest by the old gods who shed blistering tears upon witnesses - Maegor succeeded in constructing his castle within a castle - a fortified redoubt surrounded by a dry moat which could only be crossed when commanded by him, heralded the king’s might to all who heard tales of it.
