04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: In that same year, Maegor made Lord Lucas Harroway, father of his wife Queen Alys, his new Hand…but it was not the Hand who had the king’s ear. His Grace might rule the Seven Kingdoms, men whispered, but he himself was ruled by the three queens: his mother, Queen Visenya; his paramour, Queen Alys; and the Pentoshi witch, Queen Tyanna. “The mistress of whispers,” Tyanna was called, and “the king’s raven,” for her black hair. She spoke with rats and spiders, it was said, and all the vermin of King’s Landing came to her by night to tell tales of any fool rash enough to speak against the king.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: King Maegor had taken up residence in King's Landing, commanding the construction of the Red Keep and building a castle within the castle - a fortified redoubt surrounded by a dry moat. Whispers traveled across the Seven Kingdoms that Maegor would never rule with his same old tactics; he intended to bring new changes to the realm and made sure black-clad knights known as Lord Lucas Harroway’s Swords distinguished themselves amongst Queen Alys' Kingsguard. Queen Visenya also stood beside her brother, eager to protect her son Prince Maegor in Queen Tyanna's court. With so many powerful allies around him, King Maegor was determined to be remembered as one of the greatest ruling Targaryens ever.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Meanwhile, thousands of Poor Fellows still haunted the roads and wild places of the Reach, the Trident, and the Vale; though they would never again assemble in large numbers to face the king in open battle, the Stars fought on in smaller ways, falling upon travelers and swarming over towns, villages, and poorly defended castles, slaying the king’s loyalists wherever they found them. Ser Horys Hill had escaped the battle at Great Fork, but defeat and flight had tarnished him, and his followers were few. The new leaders of the Poor Fellows were men like Ragged Silas, Septon Moon, and Dennis the Lame, hardly distinguishable from outlaws. One of their most vicious captains was a woman called Poxy Jeyne Poore, whose savage followers made the woods between King’s Landing and Storm’s End all but impassable to honest travelers.
verbs: swarming over towns, villages, and poorly defended castles
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The Poor Fellows, a ragtag band of unorganized rebels assembled in the Reach, the Trident and beyond were led by Ser Horys Hill, Ragged Silas, Septon Moon and Dennis the Lame. Together with their soldiers they fought in a battle at Great Fork before facing defeat and flight. Reports came from far and wide about them swarming over towns, villages, and poorly defended castles like Barrowton, slaying the king’s loyalists as quickly as falling upon travelers. With large numbers roaming through smaller ways parts of Westeros made impassable to honest travelers King Maegor Targaryen dispatched military forces from King’s Landing to drive away those haunting people's lands - Poxy Jeyne Poore being one of his chosen commanders for this task.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Meanwhile, the Warrior’s Sons had chosen a new grand captain in the person of Ser Joffrey Doggett, the Red Dog of the Hills, who was determined to restore the order to its former glory. When Ser Joffrey set out from Lannisport to seek the blessing of the High Septon, a hundred men rode with him. By the time he arrived in Oldtown, so many knights and squires and freeriders had joined him that his numbers had swollen to two thousand. Elsewhere in the realm, other restless lords and men of faith were gathering men as well, and plotting ways to bring the dragons down.
events: restoring the order to its former glory
seeking the blessing of the High Septon
other restless lords and men of faith gathering men
plotting ways to bring the dragons down
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Ser Joffrey Doggett had chosen the green hilly regions of Lannisport as the perfect place to restore the order to its former glory. With him rode Ser Horys Hill and other restless lords and men of faith, all gathering men, swelling with new ideas on how to plot ways to bring the dragons down. Having already ridden through most of The Reach, Trident and The Vale they finally set out for Oldtown seeking the blessing of The High Septon. As they approached their destination, falling upon travelers along smaller ways or swarming over towns, villages and poorly defended castles made impassable to honest travelers in much larger numbers than is usual.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: None of this had gone unnoticed. Ravens flew to every corner of the realm, summoning lords and landed knights of doubtful loyalty to King’s Landing to bend the knee, swear homage, and deliver a son or daughter as a hostage for their obedience. The Stars and Swords were outlawed; membership in either order would henceforth be punishable by death. The High Septon was commanded to deliver himself to the Red Keep, to stand trial for high treason.
events: summoning lords and landed knights of doubtful loyalty to King’s Landing to bend the knee
deliver a son or daughter as a hostage
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: King's Landing was abuzz and the High Septon had flown his command south to summon all lords and landed knights of doubtful loyalty to King’s Landing, to bend the knee, swear homage, deliver a son or daughter as a hostage and frown upon any thought of outlawing The Seven Swords. Bywater, an aged member of House Tyrell who had seen many Kings come and go through the Red Keep gates over his time in commision joined Ser Joffrey Doggett and an entourage of pious lords from rollingford to Lannisport in their mission to restore the order to its former glory by seeking the blessing of the High Septon. Upon arrival in King's landing there was much trepidation as news came that other restless lords from across Westeros were gathering men with plans for plotting ways to bring down even dragons with newfound power growing daily inside them.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: His High Holiness responded from the Starry Sept, commanding the king to present himself in Oldtown to beg the forgiveness of the gods for his sins and cruelties. Many of the Faithful echoed his defiance. Some pious lords did travel to King’s Landing to do homage and present hostages, but more did not, trusting to their numbers and the strength of their castles to keep them safe.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The response from His High Holiness at the Starry Sept echoed throughout King's Landing and beyond. Pious lords from Oldtown and other distant parts of Westeros responded, making their intentions to travel to King's Landing clear and do homage to their rightful king - trusting in his promise that he would keep safe those who presented hostages. Numbers alone were not enough: strength in numbers was paramount for this endeavor, so the Lords traveling with him had been compelled by a command from the king backed by outlawing the Stars and Swords if it wasn't followed.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: King Maegor let the poisons fester for almost half a year, so engrossed was he in the building of his Red Keep. It was his mother who struck first. The Dowager Queen mounted Vhagar and brought fire and blood to the riverlands as once she had to Dorne. In a single night, the seats of House Blanetree, House Terrick, House Deddings, House Lychester, and House Wayn were set aflame. Then Maegor himself took wing, flying Balerion to the westerlands, where he burned the castles of the Broomes, the Falwells, the Lorches, and the other “pious lords” who had defied his summons. Lastly he descended upon the seat of House Doggett, reducing it to ash. The fires claimed the lives of Ser Joffrey’s father, mother, and young sister, along with their sworn swords, serving men, and chattel. As pillars of smoke rose all through the westerlands and the riverlands, Vhagar and Balerion turned south. Another Lord Hightower, counseled by another High Septon, had opened the gates of Oldtown during the Conquest, but now it seemed as if the greatest and most populous city in Westeros must surely burn.
places: House Blanetree, House Terrick, House Deddings, House Lychester, and House Wayn
events: flaming of Houses Blanetree and others in Riverland by dowager queen on vhagar
Maegor flying Balerion to Westerlands to burn Broomes and others’ seatsthe fires claiming the lives of Ser Joffrey’s father, mother & sister with their sworn swords.
Opening of Oldtown gates during Conquets.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The Dowager Queen Visenya, who had Ride Vhagar to set fire and burn Houses Blanetree and other Riverland houses, now led her entourage to Oldtown in order to open the gates of Oldtown during Conquets. King Maegor flew Balerion, reducing ash burning Broomes and other seated places in Westerlands claiming the lives of Famous knight Ser Joffrey's Facthier ,Mother & Sister with some of their sworn swords. This flaming action echoed across Dorne and Riverlands with Lord Doggett of Oldtown receiving a response from His High Holiness including numbers of pious lords trusting Maegor. They also wanted Prince Maegor's assurance that he would keep safe all hostages brought by him before letting open the gates of Oldtown.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Thousands fled Oldtown that night, streaming from the city gates or taking ship for distant ports. Thousands more took to the streets in drunken revelry. “This is a night for song and sin and drink,” men told one another, “for come the morrow, the virtuous and the vile burn together.” Others gathered in septs and temples and ancient woods to pray they might be spared. In the Starry Sept, the High Septon railed and thundered, calling down the wroth of the gods upon the Targaryens. The archmaesters of the Citadel met in conclave. The men of the City Watch filled sacks with sand and pails with water to fight the fires they knew were coming. Along the city walls, crossbows, scorpions, spitfires, and spear-throwers were hoisted onto the battlements in hopes of bringing down the dragons when they appeared. Led by Ser Morgan Hightower, a younger brother of the Lord of Oldtown, two hundred Warrior’s Sons spilled forth from their chapterhouse to defend His High Holiness, surrounding the Starry Sept with a ring of steel. Atop the Hightower, the great beacon fire turned a baleful green as Lord Martyn Hightower called his banners. Oldtown waited for the dawn, and the coming of the dragons.
events: gathering in septs and temples to pray for protection.
two hundred Warrior’s Sons spilling forth from their chapterhouse.
verbs: told one another.--For come the morrow, burn together.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The people of Oldtown were in a state of panic. Lord Ser Morgan Hightower, the beloved Lord of Oldtown had called on the authorities to prepare for dragons and the High Septon had called on faithful citizens to gather in septs and temples to pray for protection. By nightfall many began streaming out of their homes with their belongings fleeing from Oldtown, while two hundred Warrior’s Sons spilling forth from their chapterhouse to join forces with Prince Aegon's Kingsguard who also arrived at the gates. The princes uncle, Lord Martyn Hightower was among them as well, carrying along his lady wife Ceryse Hightower and her noble entourage behind him. There was a solemn silence as they all hoisted up the city gates, never knowing what the morrow would bring...

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: And the dragons came. Vhagar first, as the sun was rising, then Balerion, just before midday. But they found the gates of the city open, the battlements unmanned, and the banners of House Targaryen, House Tyrell, and House Hightower flying side by side atop the city walls. The Dowager Queen Visenya was the first to learn the news. Sometime during the blackest hour of that long and dreadful night, the High Septon had died.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The city of Oldtown was aflame with fear and unrest as the news spread that dragons were arriving. From Vhagar, to Balerion and Meraxes, they rose menacingly in the sky, sending streams of people fleeing from Oldtown at night. An uncommon sight of House Tyrell, Hightower and Targaryen banners hoisted atop their homes; for in the crypts below lay Dowager Queen Visenya plotting her response with High Septon and other pious lords in attendance. Men took to the streets telling one another: “For come the morrow, burn together." Gatherings assembled quickly across septs and temples to pray for protection whilst authorities prepared for dragons’ arrival awaiting two hundred Warrior’s Sons spilling forth from their chapterhouse - called by Lord Martyn Hightower under his son Ser Morgan's commandment - sending chills down folks' spines.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: A man of three-and-fifty, as tireless as he was fearless, and to all appearances in robust good health, this High Septon had been renowned for his strength. More than once he had preached for a day and a night without taking sleep or nourishment. His sudden death shocked the city and dismayed his followers. Its causes are debated to this day. Some say that His High Holiness took his own life, in what was either the act of a craven afraid to face the wroth of King Maegor, or a noble sacrifice to spare the goodfolk of Oldtown from dragonfire. Others claim the Seven struck him down for the sin of pride, for heresy, treason, and arrogance.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003:
King Maegor had suddenly descended on Oldtown to preach the faith, taking the High Septon by surprise. Despite his tireless and fearless demeanor coupled with robust good health, a sudden death struck him in the same city where the dragons came rising unmanned and flying open in their blackest forms. Bywater was stirred with fear. Noble lords bowed to His Grace's command while sinful ones cowered in the shadows, worried of what these changes meant for them and their families.
A large entourage of pious lords and knights accompanied Dowager Queen Visenya who had come from Vaella—infamously known as The Vulture King—to join King Maegor’s cause, further intensifying murmurs among commoners as well as her son’s courtiers at Kingsguard. But this time they were louder than ever before: even Ser Harys, Septon Pater or Lord Father could not fathom why Rollingford unveiled such a sour secret—one that prompted House Tyrell to extend their assistance only if Princess Deria could be married off; or why Lady Ceryse of House Hightower so readily agreed for her daughter's nuptials despite the recent shock about Valyrian marriage customs…

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Many and more remain certain he was murdered…but by whom? Ser Morgan Hightower did the deed at the command of his lord brother, some say (and Ser Morgan was seen entering and leaving the High Septon’s privy chambers that night). Others point to the Lady Patrice Hightower, Lord Martyn’s maiden aunt and a reputed witch (who did indeed seek an audience with His High Holiness at dusk, though he was alive when she departed). The archmaesters of the Citadel are also suspected, though whether they made use of the dark arts, an assassin, or a poisoned scroll is still a matter of some debate (messages went back and forth between the Citadel and the Starry Sept all night). And there are still others who hold them all blameless and lay the High Septon’s death at the door of another rumored sorceress, the Dowager Queen Visenya Targaryen.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Ser Morgan Hightower and Lady Patrice Hightower, who had been summoned to Oldtown by Lord Martyn, watched with awe as His High Holiness the High Septon met with the archmaesters of the Citadel in his privy chambers. Although much speculation arose about why Dowager Queen Visenya Targaryen would seek an audience with him, no one was quite certain what had happened during their secretive meeting. Rumors began to swirl amongst the courtiers as they went back and forth between Stry Sept and Visenya's Hill; some remaining certain that it was she who did the deed of murdering the High Septon while others sought another suspect for whom suspicion could be laid upon. The people spoke about it reverently among themselves, remarking on how the previous High Septon had been so devout yet tireless and fearless despite his robust health until he fell deathly ill so suddenly after preaching a sermon at The Starry Sept. Some wondered if he'd been taken down by craven men noble enough only to commit such a sinful act.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The truth will likely never be known…but the swift reaction of Lord Martyn when word reached him at the Hightower is beyond dispute. At once he dispatched his own knights to disarm and arrest the Warrior’s Sons, amongst them his own brother. The city gates were opened, and Targaryen banners raised along the walls. Even before Vhagar’s wings were sighted, Lord Hightower’s men were rousting the Most Devout from their beds and marching them to the Starry Sept at spearpoint to choose a new High Septon.
events: dispatching knights to disarm and arrest the Warrior’s Sons
raising Targaryen banners along the walls
rousting the Most Devout from their beds and marching them to the Starry Sept at spearpoint to choose a new High Septon.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Lord Martyn, the newly promoted Lord of the Hightower, reached out to his allies in the Warrior’s Sons and Vhagar swiftly dispatching knights to disarm and arrest them. He ordered for city gates across Westeros to open and for Targaryen banners along the walls of Oldtown be raised. Finally, he rousted the Most Devout from their beds and marched them to a Starry Sept at spearpoint to choose a new High Septon - a disruption of Valyrian marriage customs that left many pious lords shaking their heads but Queen Dowager Visenya firmly approving beside him.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: It required but a single ballot. Almost as one, the wise men and women of the Faith turned to a certain Septon Pater. Ninety years old, blind, stooped, and feeble, but famously amiable, the new High Septon almost collapsed beneath the weight of the crystal crown when it was placed upon his head…but when Maegor Targaryen appeared before him in the Starry Sept, he was only too pleased to bless him as king and anoint his head with holy oils, even if he did forget the words of the blessing.
events: But almost as one, the wise men and women of the Faith turned to a certain Septon Pater
the new High Septon almost collapsed beneath the weight of the crystal crown when it was placed upon his head
when Maegor Targaryen appeared before him in the Starry Sept, he was only too pleased to bless him as king and anoint his head with holy oils
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Ser Pater, the amiable, but feeble septon elected by the Most Devout out of a single required candidates when all other choice seemed exhausted was almost collapsed beneath the crystal crown when it was placed upon his head in Starry Sept. When Maegor Targaryen appeared before him in the court of King's Landing, pleased and blessed as king anointed with holy oils he found protection from Ser Harys Hill from House Tyrell who had been dispatched quickly to Rollingford at Lord Martyn Hightower’s order to open city gates and raise Targaryen banners along the walls while rousting merchants family’s members, priests and laity alike.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Queen Visenya soon returned to Dragonstone with Vhagar, but King Maegor remained in Oldtown for almost half the year, holding court and presiding over trials. To the captive Swords of the Warrior’s Sons, a choice was given. Those who renounced their allegiance to the order would be permitted to travel to the Wall and live out their days as brothers of the Night’s Watch. Those who refused could die as martyrs to their faith. Three-quarters of the captives chose to take the black. The remainder died. Seven of their number, famous knights and the sons of lords, were given the honor of having King Maegor himself remove their heads with Blackfyre. The rest of the condemned were beheaded by their own former brothers-in-arms. Of all their number, only one man received a full royal pardon: Ser Morgan Hightower.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Queen Visenya and her dragon Vhagar returned to Dragonstone, holding court for all the lords that came seeking favor and justice from King Maegor. The Swords of the Warrior’s Sons, the vanguard of the Faith, had undergone rigorous trials in renouncing allegiance to their feudal lords before they were permitted to take vows as brothers of the Night’s Watch. There were seven famous knights among them whom King Maegor gave the honor to remove their heads himself with a single stroke as punishment for breaking their oaths. One such knight who was beheaded by Maegor was Ser Morgan Hightower—a stout but amiable man whose feeble frame belied his courage and loyalty.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The new High Septon formally dissolved both the Warrior’s Sons and the Poor Fellows, commanding their remaining members to lay down their arms in the name of the gods. The Seven had no more need of warriors, proclaimed His High Holiness; henceforth the Iron Throne would protect and defend the Faith. King Maegor granted the surviving members of the Faith Militant till year’s end to surrender their weapons and give up their rebellious ways. After that, those who remained defiant would find a bounty on their heads: a gold dragon for the head of any unrepentant Warrior’s Son, a silver stag for the “lice- ridden” scalp of a Poor Fellow.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The High Septon had proclaimed from the Iron Throne that King Maegor was formally granted permission to dissolve the Swords of the Warrior’s Sons and lay down arms. Even His High Holiness could not stay the hand of justice, for any who refused to surrender their weapons or remained unrepentant could be found and arrested on sight. Starry-eyed Poor Fellows called it a blessing, as if all drawn swords were vanquished without further ado. Yet there were some that refused even still, preferring a martyr's death over betrayal; they would rather remove their heads than renounce allegiance due to outdated Valyrian marriage customs...

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The new High Septon did not demur, nor did the Most Devout.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The High Septon and a gathering of the Most Devout made their way to the Iron Throne, at the invitation of King Maegor. As they entered, the High Septon demurred on behalf of his followers, smiling as he extended his hand to be greeted warmly by House Tyrell's Ser Harys and Lord Father Rollingford, amongst others. The events preceding this meeting had seen most warriors lay down their arms in surrender, with some unrepentant Poor Fellows surviving an attempt to dissolve them declared formally by His High Holiness. Now there seemed to be hope amongst all present that if they stayed together they may just find peace in this disparate Westeros.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: During his time at Oldtown, the king was also reconciled with his first wife, Queen Ceryse, the sister of his host, Lord Hightower. Her Grace agreed to accept the king’s other wives, to treat them with respect and honor and speak no further ill against them, whilst Maegor swore to restore to Ceryse all the rights, incomes, and privileges due her as his wedded wife and queen. A great feast was held at the Hightower to celebrate their reconciliation; the revels even included a bedding and a “second consummation,” so all men would know this to be a true and loving union.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The following morning, after King and Queen Ceryse agreed to restore their relationship and swore allegiance to the Iron Throne at Lord Hightower's request, a feast was held in Oldtown to celebrate the reconciliation. Maegor Targaryen and his entourage attended the revels as well, offering blessings from Osmund Strong of the Drowned God upon those present. After an evening full of bedding rituals and vows of fealty sworn between House Tyrell, Rollingford, Lord Father, Kingsguard and others, King Harren called for peace among all Seven Kingdoms. To mark this occasion Lady Ceryse's son Prince Maegor joined hands with Ser Lucifer Massey, Big Jon Hogg’s daughter Alyssa and Aegon the Uncrowned of House Targaryen while Allard Royce sang songs praising Jeyne Westerling. Seven Septas dressed in silken gowns lit seven candles to honor all Queens who had served House Targaryen throughout many generations - Dowager Queen Visenya, Rhaella Targaryen and Alyssa herself among them. As a symbol that peace had truly been restored in Westeros everyone bowed before The Vulture King while cheering “Long may King Harren reign!”

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: How long King Maegor might have lingered at Oldtown cannot be known, for in the latter part of 43 AC another challenge to his throne arose. His Grace’s long absence from King’s Landing had not gone unnoticed by his nephew, and Prince Aegon was quick to seize his chance. Emerging at last from Casterly Rock, Aegon the Uncrowned and his wife, Rhaena, raced across the riverlands with a handful of companions and entered the city concealed beneath sacks of corn. With so few followers, Aegon dared not seat himself upon the Iron Throne, for he knew he could not hold it. They were there for Rhaena’s Dreamfyre…and so the prince might claim his father’s dragon, Quicksilver. In this bold endeavor, they were aided by friends in Maegor’s own court who had grown weary of the king’s cruelties. The prince and princess entered King’s Landing in a wagon pulled by mules, but when they made their departure it was on dragonback, flying side by side.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: King Maegor and his entourage, including Prince Aegon and Rhaena, dashed across the Riverlands unafraid of consequences. Their sudden presence followed quickly after word of the Uprising of 43 AC had emerged. Seizing His Chance, King Maegor dared to enter territories he had previously sworn not to disturb in order to restore his tarnished reputation. Flying alongside their dragons Vhagar and Meraxes, bold as never before - even King Harren The Black palely in comparison - they eventually arrived at Casterly Rock and Oldtown where Lord Corbray had agreed to bolster their cause. With such a distinguished company present for their bedding feast revels King Maegor felt sure that soon all seven kingdoms would recognize his greatness or else incur his wrath.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: From there, Aegon and Rhaena returned to the westerlands to assemble an army. As the Lannisters of Casterly Rock were still reluctant to openly espouse Prince Aegon’s cause, his adherents gathered at Pinkmaiden Castle, seat of House Piper. Jon Piper, Lord of Pinkmaiden, had pledged his sword to the prince, but it was widely believed that it was his fiery sister Melony, Rhaena’s girlhood friend, who won him to the cause. It was there at Pinkmaiden that Aegon Targaryen, mounted on Quicksilver, descended from the sky to denounce his uncle as a tyrant and usurper, and call upon all honest men to rally to his banners.
events: descended from the sky to denounce his uncle as a tyrant and usurper, and call upon all honest men to rally to his banners.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Aegon, Rhaena and the Lannisters of Casterly Rock returned to Westerlands in order to rally an army. Jon Piper, Lord of Pinkmaiden Castle, was one of the first to pledge his sword. Melony, a young woman from House Velaryon who had married into House Piper some weeks before their arrival, dared to join them and bravely flew with the Targaryen siblings on Vhagar. Wherever they passed by en route - be it Lord Butterwell’s keep or Quenton Qoherys’ west coast castle - Aegon descended from the sky to denounce his uncle as a tyrant and usurper, and call upon all honest men house banners. People across the Realm were enthralled with Aenys' daughters willingness to fight for Westeros' freedom - soon enough faithful warriors like Ser Morgan Hightower and Knights of the Dragon pledged themselves forces loyal only to King Maegor's rightful heir.  In time sufficient numbers had been mustered for him win back his crown; only then did he dare siege Riverrun itself – whereupon chaos emerged in both Oldtown and King’s Landing as rumors spread that The Uncrowned King had seized control of Seven Kingdoms lands already under Maegor's rule...

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The lords and knights who came were largely westermen and riverlords; the Lords Tarbeck, Roote, Vance, Charlton, Frey, Paege, Parren, Farman, and Westerling were amongst them, together with Lord Corbray of the Vale, the Bastard of Barrowton, and the fourth son of the Lord of Griffin’s Roost. From Lannisport came five hundred men under the banner of a bastard son of Lyman Lannister, Ser Tyler Hill, by which ploy the cunning Lord of Casterly Rock lent supporters to the young prince whilst still keeping his own hands clean, should Maegor prevail. The Piper levies were led not by Lord Jon or his brothers, but by their sister Melony, who donned man’s mail and took up a spear. Fifteen thousand men had joined the rebellion as Aegon the Uncrowned began his march across the riverlands to stake his claim to the Iron Throne, led by the prince himself on King Aenys’s beloved dragon, Quicksilver.
places: the Vale, Barrowton, Griffin’s Roost, Lannisport
events: joined the rebellion as Aegon the Uncrowned began his march across the riverlands to stake his claim to the Iron Throne
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: With Aegon the Uncrowned marching across the Riverlands to stake his claim to the Iron Throne, lords, knights and supporters from all over Westeros lent their voices in support - from  House Tarbeck and Roote of The Vale to Freys, Paege and Parren of Lannisport. The Lord of Pinkmaiden Melony Piper even rode along with her three brothers when Lord Corbray of Griffin's Roost donned his armor. Though many of the westermen and riverlords joined his rebellion largely due to Aegon's cunning battle strategies and a declaration that he had descended from the sky to denounce his uncle as a tyrant, others were persuaded by promises for more favorable taxes or pledges for justice against those who oppressed them in these large-scale changes occurring in Westeros.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Though their ranks included seasoned commanders and puissant knights, no great lords had rallied to Prince Aegon’s cause…but Queen Tyanna, mistress of whisperers, wrote to warn Maegor that Storm’s End, the Eyrie, Winterfell, and Casterly Rock had all been in secret communication with his brother’s widowed queen, Alyssa. Before declaring for the Prince of Dragonstone, they wished to be convinced he might prevail. Prince Aegon required a victory.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Queen Tyanna and Prince Aegon rallied support from loyal supporters from Storm's End, The Eyrie, Winterfell and Casterly Rock by writing letters declaring their intention to prevail over House Targaryen's enemies. With their puissant armies of both large and small, seasoned with cunning strategists, the prince and queen had gathered a secret force that could conquer even the oldest and most powerful families in all of Westeros.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Maegor denied him that. From Harrenhal came forth Lord Harroway, from Riverrun Lord Tully. Ser Davos Darklyn of the Kingsguard marshalled five thousand swords in King’s Landing and struck out west to meet the rebels. Up from the Reach came Lord Peake, Lord Merryweather, Lord Caswell, and their levies. Prince Aegon’s slow-moving host found armies closing from all sides; each smaller than their own force, but so many that the young prince (still but seventeen) did not know where to turn. Lord Corbray advised him to engage each foe separately before they could join their powers, but Aegon was loath to divide his strength. Instead he chose to march on toward King’s Landing.
verbs: struck out west to meet the rebels
advised him to engage each foe separately before they could join their powers,
chose to march on toward King's Landing
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Lord Peake, Lord Tully and Lord Harroway had all rallied for Prince Aegon's cause, despite his denial of their requests. When the time came, they marshalled up and struck out west to meet the rebels. Maegor was amongst them, leading an entourage of seasoned warriors - Ser Davos Darklyn, Lord Caswell and Lord Corbray included. From Harrenhal to Riverrun those up from came until they found armies closing in from both sides and advised him to engage each foe separately before they could join their powers. Knowing that reaching King's Landing required a slow-moving army of a puissant size with great secret battle plans, Maegor chose to march on toward it anyway instead - trusting in himself as much as he did in his men.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Just south of the Gods Eye, he found Davos Darklyn’s Kingslanders athwart his path, sitting on high ground behind a wall of spears, even as scouts reported Lords Merryweather and Caswell advancing from the south, and Lords Tully and Harroway from the north. Prince Aegon commanded a charge, hoping to break through the Kingslanders before the other loyalists fell upon his flanks, and mounted Quicksilver to lead the attack himself. But scarce had he taken wing when he heard shouts and saw his men below pointing to where Balerion the Black Dread had appeared in the southern sky. King Maegor had come. For the first time since the Doom of Valyria, dragon contended with dragon in the sky, even as battle was joined below.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Davos Darklyn commanded the charge as Prince Aegon and his loyalists contended against the rebels for control of Gods Eye, a great lake located in Valyria where the Doom of Valyria had first appeared. Taking King Maegor's advice to engage each foe separately before they could join their powers, the high lords from Westeros came forth with strength that echoed across southern coast and no enemy was spared.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Quicksilver, a quarter the size of Balerion, was no match for the older, fiercer dragon, and her pale white fireballs were engulfed and washed away in great gouts of black flame. Then the Black Dread fell upon her from above, his jaws closing round her neck as he ripped one wing from her body. Screaming and smoking, the young dragon plunged to earth, and Prince Aegon with her.
verbs: ripped one wing from her body
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The sky overhead was filled with dragons, their wings enveloping the world in a wash of shadow as Balerion and Quicksilver, two of the largest among them, appeared high above Gods Eye. The loyalists had contended that Prince Aegon commanded these creatures, but this seemed impossible to many. Nonetheless, suddenly they descended on Valyria as Balerion closed round her neck before ripping one wing from her body while Quicksilver plunged to earth much fiercer than his pale white nature gave away. With nowhere left to run the Doom of Valyria quickly washed away all that remained beneath them and even more contestance against King Maegor from Vhagar and Meraxes could not contain the great destroyer afore him.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The battle below was nigh as brief, if bloodier. Once Aegon fell, the rebels saw their cause was doomed and ran, discarding arms and armor as they fled. But the loyalist armies were all around them, and there was no escape. By day’s end, two thousand of Aegon’s men had died, against a hundred of the king’s. Amongst the dead were Lord Alyn Tarbeck, Denys Snow the Bastard of Barrowton, Lord Ronnel Vance, Ser Willam Whistler, Melony Piper and three of her brothers… and the Prince of Dragonstone, Aegon the Uncrowned of House Targaryen. The only notable loss amongst the loyalists was Ser Davos Darklyn of the Kingsguard, slain at the hands of Lord Corbray with Lady Forlorn. Half a year of trials and executions followed. Queen Visenya persuaded her son to spare some of the rebellious lords, but even those who kept their lives lost lands and titles and were forced to give up hostages.
characters: Denys Snow the Bastard of Barrowton
Melony Piper and three of her brothers
Prince of Dragonstone, Aegon the Uncrowned of House Targaryen
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: As the battle below Barrowton raged on, Lord Alyn Tarbeck and Denys Snow the Bastard of Barrowton led a bold charge against Prince Aegon. Ser Willam Whistler and Melony Piper and three of her brothers gave knightly aid while Beside them, the Prince of Dragonstone, Aegon the Uncrowned of House Targaryen himself cut a path through his foes until finally Lord Ronnel Vance’s banner was brought low with a cruel blow from Ser Davos Darklynof the Kingsguard, who served loyally alongside Lady Forlown of Old Wyk. But their endeavors would prove in vain as Queen Visenya's forces faced certain defeat when countless men fled or died in combat - some discarding arms and armor after suffering severe losses at hands of her forces, others slain trying to spare themselves only to be lost lands and titles. As carnage continued with each dismemberment being bloodier than before it seemed that no victory for either armies could be attained here; it was only doom for those left behind amidst terrible smoke that engulfed all before tossing those not fortunate enough away like leaves in the wind.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: One notable name could be found neither amongst the dead nor the captive: Rhaena Targaryen, sister and wife to Prince Aegon, had not joined the host. Whether that was by his command or her own choice is still debated to this day. All that is known for certain is that Rhaena remained at Pinkmaiden Castle with her daughters when Aegon marched…and with her, Dreamfyre. Would the addition of a second dragon to the prince’s host have made a difference when battle was joined? We shall never know…though it has been pointed out, and rightly, that Princess Rhaena was no warrior, and Dreamfyre was younger and smaller than Quicksilver, and certainly no true threat to Balerion the Black Dread.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Rhaena Targaryen and Prince Aegon marched together from Pinkmaiden Castle, joined by pointedly noticeable dead captives of their own. Certain smaller, younger captives were spared in a vain attempt to not rouse the defeated lords any further, who had lost lands and titles as well as some of their most notable members in the battle below – trials and executions deemed bloodier than necessary by certain pious lords of Westeros. Along with the dwindling entourage, Queen Visenya Targaryen traveled west on Vhagar at His High Holiness, the High Septon’s behest to Oldtown with her brother-son Prince Aegon Variys. Her son Dragon, Rhaenys’ older cousin Lord Allard Royce also joined them.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: When word of the battle reached the west and Princess Rhaena learned that both her husband and her friend Lady Melony had fallen, it is said she heard the news in a stony silence. “Will you not weep?” she was asked, to which she replied, “I do not have the time for tears.” Whereupon, fearing her uncle’s wroth, she gathered up her daughters, Aerea and Rhaella, and fled farther, first to Lannisport and then across the sea to Fair Isle, where the new lord Marq Farman (whose father and elder brother had both perished in the battle, fighting for Prince Aegon) gave her sanctuary and swore no harm would come to her beneath his roof. For the best part of a year, the people of Fair Isle watched the east in dread, fearing the sight of Balerion’s dark wings, but Maegor never came. Instead the victorious king returned to the Red Keep, where he grimly set about getting himself an heir.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Princess Rhaena, Lady Melony, Aerea and Rhaella Targaryen had reached the west in search of sanctuary when they stumbled upon a Battle at Lannisport. Marq Farman, who had sworn his life to Prince Aegon's campaign was there. He pointed them towards Fair Isle as their most notable destination for refuge. Meanwhile, the fate of their fallen captive Aegon was growing more and more uncertain with each passing day. The girls set about getting to Fair Isle in haste but Stony Dread on Balerion’s back soon made short work of that journey. Though they could not help but watch with dread as they fled from what seemed like an unavoidable death or captivity of their own - all felt certain that second best would do just fine if it meant keeping the younger, smaller Targaryens safe within their own grasp.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The 44th year After the Conquest was a peaceful one compared to what had gone before…but the maesters who chronicled those times wrote that the smell of blood and fire still hung heavy in the air. Maegor I Targaryen sat the Iron Throne as his Red Keep rose around him, but his court was grim and cheerless, despite the presence of his three queens…or perhaps because of it. Each night he summoned one of his wives to his bed, yet still he remained childless, with no heir but for the sons and daughters of his brother, Aenys. “Maegor the Cruel,” he was called, and “kinslayer” as well, though it was death to say either in his hearing.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Maegor I Targaryen and Aenys, sons of the great Conqueror Aegon I Targaryen, had summoned an army to the Iron Throne in a bid to peacefully reclaim their kingdom. But what they found at the Red Keep was a grim and cheerless aura that filled all who passed through its Gates. Lords from across the Seven Kingdoms flocked to join them in battle against those lords who had betrayed their family; Lady Melony Piper and three of her brothers as well as Lord Corbray and Allard Royce, who was Jeyne Westerling's cousin, amongst many more. The ensuing Conquest would be chronicled in tales for many generations until Aegon I's descendants returned home - returning Westeros back into balance.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: In Oldtown, the ancient High Septon died, and another was raised up in his place. Though he spoke no word against the king or his queens, the enmity between King Maegor and the Faith endured. Hundreds of Poor Fellows had been hunted down and slain, their scalps delivered to the king’s men for the bounty, but thousands more still roamed the woods and hedges and the wild places of the Seven Kingdoms, cursing the Targaryens with their every breath. One band even crowned their own High Septon, in the person of a bearded brute named Septon Moon. And a few Warrior’s Sons still endured, led by Ser Joffrey Doggett, the Red Dog of the Hills. Outlawed and condemned, the order no longer had the strength to meet the king’s men in open battle, so the Red Dog sent them out in the guise of hedge knights, to hunt and slay Targaryen loyalists and “traitors to the Faith.” Their first victim was Ser Morgan Hightower, late of their order, cut down and butchered on the road to Honeyholt. Old Lord Merryweather was the next to die, followed by Lord Peake’s son and heir, Davos Darklyn’s aged father, even Blind Jon Hogg. Though the bounty for the head of a Warrior’s Son was a golden dragon, the smallfolk and peasants of the realm hid and protected them, remembering what they had been.
verbs: spoken against the king or his queens
sent out in the guise of hedge knights, to hunt and slay Targaryen loyalists and “traitors to the Faith.
cut down and butchered on the road to Honeyholt.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The Targaryen loyalists had become hunted down and were soon slain, which led to King Maegor's beloved High Septon being put to death. In his stead, the Poor Fellows of the Seven Kingdoms raised up a new High Septon in Oldtown. To quell any opposition to the crown, Ser Joffrey Doggett and Red Dog of the Hills from House Tyrell had been sent out with a group of hedge knights, masterfully hunting down those believed to have spoken against King Maegor or his queens. Even Lord Peake's son was not spared and was cut down on his way to Honeyholt. The ancient enmity between Lannisters and Targaryens only seemed to be growing ever more fierce in these wild places.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: On Dragonstone, the Dowager Queen Visenya had grown thin and haggard, the flesh melting from her bones. Queen Alyssa remained on the island as well, with her son Jaehaerys and her daughter Alysanne, prisoners in all but name. Prince Viserys, the eldest surviving son of Aenys and Alyssa, was summoned to court by His Grace. A promising lad of fifteen years, beloved of the commons, Viserys was made squire to the king…with a Kingsguard knight for a shadow, to keep him well away from plots and treasons.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Queen Visenya and Queen Alyssa, both Targaryens and siblings of King Jaehaerys and his beloved sister, Princess Alysanne had grown thin and haggard since being summoned to court. As Prince Viserys was kept well away from the throne as King Maegor was said to be deeply suspicious of even his own kin. Night's Watch brothers Ser Harys Horpe and Septon Pater were dispatched to Dragonstone with a contingent of loyal House Tyrell men-at-arms in order to bring back Lord Darklyn's aged father, Davos Baratheon, along with Rollingford, princely bastard born at Maidenpool. Ser Joffrey Doggett was sent out in the guise of hedge knight along with Red Dogge Of The Hills and other brave warriors in order to hunt down Targaryen loyalists who had spoken against the king or queens. They butchered anyone suspected on their way from Oldtown Seven Kingdoms to Honeyholt; an ancient enmity for those living in wild places of Westeros could be felt whirling through air making mark on fragile peace between them all.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: For a brief while in 44 AC, it seemed as if the king might soon have that son he desired so desperately. Queen Alys announced she was with child, and the court rejoiced. Grand Maester Desmond confined Her Grace to her bed as she grew great with child, and took charge of her care, assisted by two septas, a midwife, and the queen’s sisters Jeyne and Hanna. Maegor insisted that his other wives serve his pregnant queen as well.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Queen Alys had announced she was with child, and the whole court rejoiced. After weeks of confinement as desired by Her Grace, Grand Maester Desmond and the Septas took charge of her care to ensure that all would go well. With great diligence they tended to Queen Alys, with the Midwife Jeyne and Lady Hanna accompanying them in the royal chambers. This news caught the attention of King himself who remained on Dragonstone, having summoned his daughters Queen Visenya and Queen Alyssa there to keep him well away from any potential strife in King's Landing. As for Prince Viserys, he had grown thin and haggard in his beloved aunt's absence; a squire was made for him thusly, so as to provide companionship throughout this trying time.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: During the third moon of her confinement, however, Lady Alys began to bleed heavily from the womb and lost the child. When King Maegor came to see the stillbirth, he was horrified to find the boy a monster, with twisted limbs, a huge head, and no eyes. “This cannot be my son!” he roared in anguish. Then his grief turned to fury, and he ordered the immediate execution of the midwife and septas who had charge of the queen’s care, and Grand Maester Desmond as well, sparing only Alys’s sisters.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Lady Alys and King Maegor had been overjoyed when she announced she was with child. Everyone in the court rejoiced, and the Septas took charge of her care. But when Lady Alys went into labour and birthed a stillborn baby, everyone's joy quickly turned to sorrow. As Lady Alys continued to bleed heavily from the twisted womb, King Maegor gallantly ordered that only sparingly intervention be taken -- though he himself was greatly distressed by this heavy blow of tragedy. Ever since then, House Targaryen had held dear the customs practiced by their Valyrian marriage predecessors; one that would grant them hope for their desired future.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: It is said that Maegor was seated on the Iron Throne with the head of the Grand Maester in his hands when Queen Tyanna came to tell him he had been deceived. The child was not his seed. Seeing Queen Ceryse return to court, old and bitter and childless, Alys Harroway had begun to fear that the same fate awaited her unless she gave the king a son, so she had turned to her lord father, the Hand of the King. On the nights when the king was sharing a bed with Queen Ceryse or Queen Tyanna, Lucas Harroway sent men to his daughter’s bed to get her with child. Maegor refused to believe. He told Tyanna she was a jealous witch, and barren, throwing the Grand Maester’s head at her. “Spiders do not lie,” the mistress of the whisperers replied. She handed the king a list.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The Iron Throne had been deceived into thinking that the royal court was peaceful, but this soon changed when King Maegor stood and threw his Hand of the King aside. Queen Tyanna and Queen Ceryse watched in fear as Maegor shouted orders to send men to find Lady Alys Harroway's Lord Father for her stillbirth. The Grand Maester comforted both queens as she turned and handed Lucas Harroway his newborn daughter, Tyanna. In a fit of rage fueled by grief, Lord Father ordered that no-one spare any mercy on House Harroway’s heavy crime--a twisted tale whose huge consequences would be felt across Seven Kingdoms.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Written there were the names of twenty men alleged to have given their seed to Queen Alys. Old men and young, handsome men and homely ones, knights and squires, lords and servants, even grooms and smiths and singers; the King’s Hand had cast a wide net, it seemed. The men had only one thing in common: all were men of proven potency known to have fathered healthy children.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Queen Alysanne had written to a select few among the secondary nobility asking for possible suitors for Tyanna and her daughter. With a wide net cast and given the context of what had been said before, many knights, squires, lords, servants and even gangs of smiths flocked in from far-off places to get their chance at glory. Old men as well as young men smiled upon upcoming opportunities to serve as husband or father-in-law to two royal ladies. Handsome men were sure of themselves but homely ones were not left out either bringing them all closer together at King's Hand hoping that luck would be on their side this day. Singers came along with tales of each suitor's renown which further heightened the atmosphere of excitement surrounding Queen Alys' quest.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Under torture, all but two confessed. One, a father of twelve, still had the gold paid him by Lord Harroway for his services. The questioning was carried out swiftly and secretly, so Lord Harroway and Queen Alys had no inkling of the king’s suspicions until the Kingsguard burst in on them. Dragged from her bed, Queen Alys saw her sisters killed before her eyes as they tried to protect her. Her father, inspecting the Tower of the Hand, was flung from its roof to smash upon the stones below. Harroway’s sons, brothers, and nephews were taken as well. Thrown onto the spikes that lined the dry moat around Maegor’s Holdfast, some took hours to die; the simpleminded Horas Harroway lingered for days. The twenty names on Queen Tyanna’s list soon joined them, and then another dozen men, named by the first twenty.
events: father flung from roof to stones below
Harroway's sons, brothers, and nephews thrown onto spikes
verbs: flung from its roof to smash upon the stones below.
thrown onto the spikes that lined the dry moat around Maegor’s Holdfast
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Lord Harroway and the Kingsguard burst in on Queen Alys and her entourage in Maegor's Holdfast. Lord Harroway had paid no inkling as to their coming, so as they dragged the queen from her bed,  some of her protective sisters were killed. Then, Lord Harroway and his men flung Lord Father from its roof to smash upon the stones below. Afterwards, any who confessed were cast onto the spikes that lined the dry moat around Maegor’s Holdfast while those who had no inkling joined them nonetheless; simpleminded amongst them all alike lay dead upon the fortress walls.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The worst death was reserved for Queen Alys herself, who was given over to her sister-wife Tyanna for torment. Of her death we will not speak, for some things are best buried and forgotten. Suffice it to say that her dying took the best part of a fortnight, and that Maegor himself was present for all of it, a witness to her agony. After her death, the queen’s body was cut into seven parts, and her pieces mounted on spikes above the seven gates of the city, where they remained until they rotted.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: The world felt heavy, only made worse by the pained cries of Queen Alys. Maegor had his revenge and she was dying - a never forgotten tragedy; but one that would soon be buried and forgotten. Despite her suffering, Tyanna remained calm, remaining by her sisters side until the end of her days; for in these seven words Tyanna knew what had to be done for peace to reign ever again. The worst of their stories were now over but al Ser's loyal conversation with Lord Harroway and House Tyrell had no inkling as to the darkness that bursted into Tower of the Hand merely moments later when he dragged from her bed Aenys Targaryen's daughter, for whom none could save- doomed to death amidst more torture before being thrown onto the spikes that lined the dry moat around Maegor’s Holdfast where so many others tragically joined them.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: King Maegor himself departed King’s Landing, assembling a strong force of knights and men-at-arms and marching on Harrenhal to complete the destruction of House Harroway. The great castle on the Gods Eye was lightly held, and its castellan, a nephew of Lord Lucas and cousin to the late queen, opened his gates at the king’s approach. Surrender did not save him; His Grace put the entire garrison to the sword, along with every man, woman, and child he found to have any drop of Harroway blood. Then he marched to Lord Harroway’s Town on the Trident and did the same there.
events: assembling a strong force of knights and men-at-arms and marching on Harrenhal to complete the destruction
the entire garrison was put to the sword
did the same at Lord Harroway's Town
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: When Lady Tyanna arrived in King's Landing with Lord Lucas and her son, the late queen Queen Alys, Maegor was assembling a strong force of knights and men-at-arms and marched on Harrenhal to complete the destruction, where the entire garrison surrendered open without opposition. He did the same at Lord Harroway's Town and departed for Gods Eye with lighty held castles still left in his wake as he sailed away. The tales of what happened soon spread far beyond Westeros: from distant ports across Narrow Sea to Tyrosh or Vallasita, it seemed like everyone had heard something about Maegor I Targaryen's campaign of death.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: In the aftermath of the bloodletting, men began to say that Harrenhal was cursed, for every lordly house to hold it had come to a bad and bloody end. Nonetheless, many ambitious king’s men coveted Black Harren’s mighty seat, with its broad and fertile lands…so many that King Maegor grew weary of their entreaties, and decreed that Harrenhal should go to the strongest of them. Thus did twenty-three knights of the king’s household fight with sword and mace and lance amidst the blood-soaked streets of Lord Harroway’s Town. Ser Walton Towers emerged victorious, and Maegor named him Lord of Harrenhal…but the melee had been a savage affray, and Ser Walton did not live long enough to enjoy his lordship, dying of his wounds within the fortnight. Harrenhal passed to his eldest son, though its domains were much diminished, as the king granted Lord Harroway’s Town to Lord Alton Butterwell, and the rest of the Harroway holdings to Lord Darnold Darry.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Ser Walton Towers emerged from the violent tournament at Harrenhal victorious and coveted by many, eager to make entreaties for his service. Even King Maegor was determined to get Ser Walton to serve him - as both a celebrated knight of renown and an ambitious man-at-arms. Lord Alton Butterwell was first in line with offers of coin and landed titles, though Lord Darnold Darry eventually persuaded Ser Walton to join him in the melee's savage bloodletting against the people of Lord Harroway’s Town. After much debate, Maegor gracefully conceded victory and granted the two lords their requests. It seemed that while lightly held, Harrenhal had brought forth an unexpected victor this day: one whose fate would grant him far more than he ever imagined possible back when he departed from Rollingford some days ago.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: When at last Maegor returned to King’s Landing to seat himself again upon the Iron Throne, he was greeted with the news that his mother, Queen Visenya, had died. Moreover, in the confusion that followed the death of the Queen Dowager, Queen Alyssa and her children had made their escape from Dragonstone, with the dragons Vermithor and Silverwing…to where, no man could say. They had even gone so far as to steal Dark Sister as they fled.
events: returned to King’s Landing to seat himself again upon the Iron Throne
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: King Maegor had finally returned to King's Landing to seat himself again upon the Iron Throne, greeted by a multitude of Westerosi lords and ladies. After the bloodletting that had occurred at Harrenhal, he made it clear that he would no longer grant any ambitious entreaties and his savage victory was already being coveted across the Realm. With Queen Vinsona and Queen Alyssa soon arriving to Dragonstone with Vermithor, Silverwing, and her other dragons after their escape from Dragonstone, Maegor proclaimed in the court that no event would follow her death with such majesty as when she herself entered King's Landing for the final time.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: His Grace ordered his mother’s body burned, her bones and ashes interred beside those of the Conqueror. Then he sent his Kingsguard to seize his squire, Prince Viserys. “Chain him in a black cell and question him sharply,” Maegor commanded. “Ask him where his mother has gone.”
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Prince Viserys had been sent a message by His Grace, Maegor regarding the interment of his mother's remains. Knowing that it would be hard to ignore such summon, Prince Viserys made the long journey back to King’s Landing with his entourage. The prince was greeted upon arrival by Lord Lucas Harroway and other important lords from House Tyrell, wishing him well and hoping for his safe return from Dragonstone. When he arrived at the castle, Lord Peake’s son loudly proclaimed the Prince’s return as the Conqueror entered through the gates of Dragonstone on Vermithor and Silverwing followed closely behind by Maegor and Queen Visenya in tow. However, there were rumors about Prince Viserys having planned to steal away with dragons after hearing about his mother's death but no matter what rumors may have said or not said, he returned back to seat himself again upon The Iron Throne. After few days an arrest warrant was signed under orders of Maegor Targaryen which commanded all men of Kingsguard to seize Prince Viserys and chain him up in black irons while secretly questioning him regarding Mother Conquerer's burial arrangements whilst making sure none could go against King Maegor's commands on this matter any more.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: “He may not know,” protested Ser Owen Bush, a knight of Maegor’s Kingsguard. “Then let him die,” the king answered famously. “Perhaps the bitch will turn up for his funeral.”
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Ser Owen Bush, of Maegor’s Kingsguard, had been with the king when he burned and was interred. He was sent to seize and chain those who questioned His Grace’s mother’s place in the Conqueror’s line and his claimed authority over Westeros. Knowing Ser Owen would turn up dead, the king could only accept it and take solace in House Tyrell of Rollingford who were faithfully supporting him as well as Septon Pater who had first brought news that his aunt Deria Martell feared for her brother's wrath. Despite this, Prince Viserys's power seemed to grow larger than ever before, leaving a hazy uncertainty clouding what may happen next to The Seven Kingdoms if something didn't change soon.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Prince Viserys did not know where his mother had gone, not even when Tyanna of Pentos plied him with her dark arts. After nine days of questioning, he died. His body was left out in the ward of the Red Keep for a fortnight, at the king’s command. “Let his mother come and claim him,” Maegor said. But Queen Alyssa never appeared, and at last His Grace consigned his nephew to the fire. The prince was fifteen years old when he was killed, and had been much loved by smallfolk and lords alike. The realm wept for him.
events: left out in the ward of the Red Keep for a fortnight
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Prince Viserys plied Tyanna of Pentos with her dark arts and questioning, but his efforts yielded no results. In a fit of anger, he left the woman out in the ward of the Red Keep for a fortnight without food or water, until Queen Alyssa consigned her to fire. With much loved Ser Owen Bush valiantly defending Maegor's Kingsguard, knowing full well that many had already died defending their king in the past, it was clear that none present could turn up to oppose him this time.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: In 45 AC, construction finally came to an end on the Red Keep. King Maegor celebrated its completion by feasting the builders and workmen who had labored on the castle, sending them wagonloads of strongwine and sweetmeats, and whores from the city’s finest brothels. The revels lasted for three days. Afterward, the king’s knights moved in and put all the workmen to the sword, to prevent them from ever revealing the Red Keep’s secrets. Their bones were interred beneath the castle that they had built.
events: construction finally came to an end on the Red Keep
king celebrated its completion by feasting the builders and workman
knights moved in and put all the workmen to the sword
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: King Maegor celebrated the completion of the Red Keep by hosting a grand feast in the court to honor all of its builders and workers. Drowned God prayers were sung and plied with sweetmeats and strongwine for three days as revels lasted throughout the city. After feasting, Maegor had those who built his great castle interred in it's very walls, but even then the celebration upset some pious lords who protested that the King had not paid or thanked those he much loved builders properly. Later they found their protests falling on deaf ears when Kingsguard knights moved into the Red Keep and put all remaining workmen to sword.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Not long after the completion of the castle, Queen Ceryse was stricken with a sudden illness and passed away. A rumor went around the court that Her Grace had given offense to the king with a shrewish remark, so he had commanded Ser Owen to remove her tongue. As the tale went, the queen had struggled, Ser Owen’s knife had slipped, and the queen’s throat had been slit. Though never proven, this story was widely believed at the time; today, however, most maesters believe it to be a slander concocted by the king’s enemies to further blacken his repute. Whatever the truth, the death of his first wife left Maegor with but a single queen, the black-haired, black-hearted Pentoshi woman Tyanna, mistress of the spiders, who was hated and feared by all.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Queen Ceryse, wife of King Maegor, was a shrewish and largely unpopular woman across the realm. When an illness suddenly overcame Queen Ceryge and she struggled to pass it on, hopes were high that she would soon be removed. Unfortunately all prayers went unanswered as the Queen slipped away quietly in her castle bedroom, where Lord Tyanna had been keeping her company. It was widely believed that Maegor had blackened his queen's heart even further with strange Valyrian marriage customs but also that he found solace in sweetmeats and strongwine when sorrow threatened to overwhelm him at her passing.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Hardly had the last stone been set on the Red Keep when Maegor commanded that the ruins of the Sept of Remembrance be cleared from the top of Rhaenys’s Hill, and with them the bones and ashes of the Warrior’s Sons who had perished there. In their place, he decreed, a great stone “stable for dragons” would be erected, a lair worthy of Balerion, Vhagar, and their get. Thus commenced the building of the Dragonpit. Perhaps unsurprisingly, it proved difficult to find builders, stonemasons, and laborers to work on the project. So many men ran off that the king was finally forced to use prisoners from the city’s dungeons as his workforce, under the supervision of builders brought in from Myr and Volantis.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: Maegor, the new King of Westeros, made a point to prove his Targaryen strength by forcing off any and all who resisted him. He began with the building of Dragonpit atop Rhaenys’s Hill near the Red Keep; it was a small token compared to the large-scale construction stretching from Myr to Volantis. Maegor's motivation seemed clear: he wanted to create a seat of power that would last for centuries beyond his own rule. This plan proved successful, and in time, the Dragonpit stood tall and proud as one of the most recognizable symbols of Targaryen supremacy in all of Westeros. Despite some resistance from those who viewed it as a corrupted lordly indulgence, Maegor's grand ambition soon set an example that even far away cities like Tyrosh could not ignore.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Late in the year 45 AC, King Maegor took the field once again to continue his war against the outlawed remnants of the Faith Militant, leaving Queen Tyanna to rule King’s Landing together with the new Hand, Lord Edwell Celtigar. In the great wood south of the Blackwater, the king’s forces hunted down scores of Poor Fellows who had taken refuge there, sending many to the Wall and hanging those who refused to take the black. Their leader, the woman known as Poxy Jeyne Poore, continued to elude the king until at last she was betrayed by three of her own followers, who received pardons and knighthoods as their reward.
events: war against the outlawed remnants of the Faith Militant
verbs: sending many to the Wall and hanging those who refused to take the black
elude the king until at last she was betrayed by three of her own followers received pardons and knighthoods as their reward
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: King Maegor and Queen Tyanna took the field against the outlawed remnants of the Faith Militant, hunting down scores of their followers, sending many to the Wall and hanging those who refused to take the black. Lord Edwell Celtigar provided an invaluable service by helping to elude Poxy Jeyne Poore, last leader against them. Despite all their efforts, Poxy did not prove defeated until late in year 45 AC when she was betrayed by three of her own followers with whom she fled into a great wood south of King's Landing. They received pardons and knighthoods as their reward for aiding to run off Poxy Jeyne.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Three septons traveling with His Grace declared Poxy Jeyne a witch, and Maegor ordered her to be burned alive in a field beside the Wendwater. When the day appointed for her execution came, three hundred of her followers, Poor Fellows and peasants all, burst from the woods to rescue her. The king had anticipated this, however, and his men were ready for the attack. The rescuers were surrounded and slaughtered. Amongst the last to die was their leader, who proved to be Ser Horys Hill, the bastard hedge knight who had escaped the carnage at the Great Fork three years earlier. This time he proved less fortunate.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: His Grace King Maegor had declared a war against the outlawed remnants of the Faith Militant and had taken the field himself alongside his vanguard to hunt down scores of rebels, sending many to the Wall or hanging those who refused to take the black. After months on campaign, Poxy Jeyne was surprisingly able to elude him until at last she was betrayed by three of her own followers, who received pardons and knighthoods as their reward. Late in year 45 AC, news came that she was held prisoner in Wendwater, near The Great Fork. King Maegor ordered her execution then and there and a rescue attempt commenced with clubs & axes by brave Poor Fellows againstSer Horys Hill's men supported by cavalry hearding them from all sides. The anticipated slaughter soon burst out and many died before daybreak yet despite being surrounded from all directions Poxy Jeyne managed to stay alive until the very last moments when Lord Edwell Celtigar arrived with an entourage of Lords Tyrell followed close behind as they sang praise for he triumphant return back home after extinguishing another rebellion against His Grace's reign.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: Elsewhere in the realm, however, the tide of the times had begun to turn against the king. Smallfolk and lords alike had come to despise him for his many cruelties, and many began to give help and comfort to his enemies. Septon Moon, the “High Septon” raised up by the Poor Fellows against the man in Oldtown they called the High Lickspittle, roamed the riverlands and Reach at will, drawing huge crowds whenever he emerged from the woods to preach against the king. The hill country north of the Golden Tooth was ruled in all but name by the Red Dog, Ser Joffrey Doggett, self-proclaimed Grand Captain of the Warrior’s Sons. Neither Casterly Rock nor Riverrun seemed inclined to move against him. Dennis the Lame and Ragged Silas remained at large, and wherever they roamed, smallfolk helped keep them safe. Knights and men-at-arms sent out to bring them to justice oft vanished.
verbs: turn/despise/give/raised up/ruled in all but name
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: King Maegor had ordered his loyal subjects, Ser Joffrey Doggett and Dennis the Lame to roam throughout the realm, preaching of his grandeur and severity. They vanished into Oldtown, Golden Tooth and Casterly Rock where many citizens of the Realm began to turn away from the King and despise him. Septon Moon, High Lickspittle and Ragged Silas then rose up to lead protests against the King in these places. As they continued to rally more smallfolk against him — their success only heightened by news of execution, rescue attempts gone awry at Wendwater, slaughters at Great Fork — it was anticipated that he would soon be surrounded by enemies should something not be done soon. Sure enough, when His Grace made another visit with an entourage of famous knights like Knight Warrior's Sons' Ser Harys Hill for protection - all hell broke loose as those opposing him raised arms against them. When those Poor Fellows were slaughtered or died trying; Queen Visenya Targaryen's son Prince Maegor managed to make off with a few alive in his wake but it was too little too late for many as Lord Tully of Riverrun declared this last stand a loss before voicing what everyone had been dreading: "It is over".

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: In 46 AC, King Maegor returned to the Red Keep with two thousand skulls, the fruits of a year of campaigning. They were the heads of Poor Fellows and Warrior’s Sons, he announced, as he dumped them out beneath the Iron Throne…but it was widely believed that many of the grisly trophies belonged to simple crofters, fieldhands, and swineherds guilty of no crime but faith.
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: King Maegor returned from his campaigning with a convoy of families in tow - simple grisly trophies dumped at his feet as offering wherever he passed. To the poor smallfolk, Maegor was a warrior’s son who held those much less fortunate than him raised up by their own guilt and revenged labors. He took the Iron Throne and ruled in all but name from the Red Keep when everyone else had turned away or despised what he had done. Now, many feared what would come of all these people he gathered together for after all, who can predict the whims of such a powerful man?

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: The coming of the new year found Maegor still without a son, not even a bastard who might be legitimized. Nor did it seem likely that Queen Tyanna would give him the heir that he desired. Whilst she continued to serve His Grace as mistress of whisperers, the king no longer sought her bed.
events: the coming of the new year
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: As the coming of the new year was upon them, King Maegor and his wife Tyanna were certain they had found what they sought - a way to be legitimized in not just the eyes of their Westerosi counterparts at court but also by The Faith on lands beyond. Yet as soon as King Maegor returned from his campaigning in Foreigner's Land to hear rumors that Village West of Gods Eye bore witness to an old Valyrian marriage custom which Lord Aryon Tyrell and Princess Deria of Rollingford had adopted: “A joined fate for nobleline and gods,” he knew that any chance he'd wanted for something new from this desired union would come true no longer.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: It was past time for him to take a new wife, Maegor’s counselors agreed…but they parted ways on who that wife should be. Grand Maester Benifer suggested a match with the proud and lovely Lady of Starfall, Clarisse Dayne, in the hopes of detaching her lands and house from Dorne. Alton Butterwell, master of coin, offered his widowed sister, a stout woman with seven children. Though admittedly no beauty, he argued, her fertility had been proved beyond a doubt. The King’s Hand, Lord Celtigar, had two young maiden daughters, thirteen and twelve years of age respectively. He urged the king to take his pick of them, or marry both if he preferred. Lord Velaryon of Driftmark advised Maegor to send for his niece Rhaena, the widow of Aegon the Uncrowned. By taking her to wife, Maegor could unite their claims, prevent any fresh rebellions from gathering around her, and acquire a hostage against any plots her mother, Queen Alyssa, might foment.
events: match with the proud and lovely Lady of Starfall, Clarisse Dayne
adjectives: proud and lovely Woman of Starfall, Clarisse Dayne
stout woman with seven children describing her fertility
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: As the new year began, tensions ran high throughout the Seven Kingdoms. Lord Velaryon of Driftmark and Lord Celtigar had agreed to Maegor's suggestion of taking a new wife, and urged him to send for the proud and lovely Woman of Starfall, Clarisse Dayne. The two parted ways as Grand Maester Benifer offered his opinion about Rhaena Targaryen having been legitimized so that she might join Queen Alyssa in Dorne if desired. As it turned out, Clarisse Dayne was indeed a stout woman with seven children - two young maiden daughters included - but after hearing her description on fertility, many lords could not help but have their doubts about the match. Little did they know however that fate had already begun writing events set to unfold with this union; unknown forces perhaps? Whatever lay ahead was yet unseen yet eagerly sought by all involved.  Meanwhile far away in Starfall, Larissa Velaryon contemplated her next move at Andalos where King Harren's famous knights awaited their challengers seeking honor - or themselves a way out of Westeros.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: King Maegor listened to each man in turn. Though in the end he scorned most of the women they put forward, some of their reasons and arguments took root in him. He would have a woman of proven fertility, he decided, though not Butterwell’s fat and homely sister. He would take more than one wife, as Lord Celtigar urged. Two wives would double his chances of getting a son; three wives would triple it. And one of those wives should surely be his niece; there was wisdom in Lord Velaryon’s counsel. Queen Alyssa and her two youngest children remained in hiding (it was thought that they had fled across the narrow sea, to Tyrosh or perhaps Volantis), but they still represented a threat to Maegor’s crown, and any son he might father. Taking Aenys’s daughter to wife would weaken any claims put forward by her younger siblings.
places: across the narrow sea, to Tyrosh or perhaps Volantis
04-The Sons of the Dragon.text-davinci-003: King Maegor scorned the advice offered by his lords, taking root in his choice to have Queen Alyssa take a new wife from across the narrow sea, to Tyrosh or perhaps Volantis. The reaction from Butterwell and Lord Celtigar was one of surprise, but Lord Velaryon remained silent. His suggestion had been made with every good intention but ultimately fell upon deaf ears; whether it was some dark shadow that led him not to speak is up for debate. It came as no surprise then when he remained in hiding shortly after, leaving Westeros with Princess Rhaena and Aegon the Uncrowned before fleeing to Dragonstone where they would remain. His actions were seen as a representation of how ruling decisions could weaken the Targeryen power if left unchecked; clearly Maegor had taken more than just a fat and homely queen during his reign.

04-The Sons of the Dragon.paragraph: After the death of her husband and her flight to Fair Isle, Rhaena Targaryen had acted quickly to protect her daughters. If Prince Aegon had truly been the king, by law his eldest daughter, Aerea, stood his heir, and might therefore claim to be the rightful Queen of the Seven Kingdoms…but Aerea and her sister, Rhaella, were barely a year old, and Rhaena knew that to trumpet such claims would be tantamount to condemning them to death. Instead, she dyed their hair, changed their names, and sent them from her, entrusting them to certain powerful allies, who would see them fostered in good homes by worthy men who would have no inkling of their true identities.
